My daughter and I spent a lot of the weekend playing tennis and watching Wimbledon â€” Womenâ€™s, Menâ€™s, and Doubles. Itâ€™s such a tremendous event, and weâ€™re committed to going live next summer. You can't help but notice the Nike, Asics, Yonex, Adidas branding, and what feels like every beverage distributor on the planet. But Wimbledon reminds us: itâ€™s not the gear that wins championships â€” itâ€™s execution, strategy, and the ability to adapt in real time under high-pressure situations.

I couldnâ€™t help but think the same is true in automation.
Robots â€” like rackets and shoes â€” are now standard issue. Everyone has access to the hardware. But not everyone knows how to play the game.
What separates leaders isnâ€™t who has the most robots â€” itâ€™s how those robots are integrated into workflows, fueled by data, and tuned for meaningful business outcomes.

The real advantage lies in how you read the opponent and court â€” optimizing for throughput, cost, compliance, and experience.
When automation is paired with real-time analytics and process intelligence, organizations move from simply â€œshowing upâ€ to winning with intent.
In this new era, the hardware is just the serve.
The rally â€” and the win â€” comes from how you execute point after point, process after process.

Congrats to Sinner and Swiatek â€” see you next year!

content:
âœ¨ A Full-Circle Journey Rooted in Possibility âœ¨

Some milestones stay with you forever.

For me, one was joining #Leapwork (then #LeapTest) as an early employee. Back then, we were a small, focused team with a bold vision: to make automation simpler, smarter, and accessible to all.

From the outset, it was an all-hands-on-deck journey. I had the privilege of building and scaling teams across #CustomerExperience, #CustomerSuccess, #Technology, #HR, #Operations, and #ProfessionalServices. Every challenge brought growth, every success brought momentum.

As the years went by, Leapwork evolved into a category leader: an incredible product backed by an extraordinary culture. We watched our customers do amazing things: reimagine processes, achieve efficiencies they once thought impossible, and spark innovation within their organizations.

Over time, one insight became clear: in the world of automation, there's always more value waiting to be unlocked.

Not because of limitations, but because in dynamic industries like banking, healthcare, e-commerce, telecom, and manufacturing, it's easy to address the "now" and miss the opportunity to tap into the full potential of what's possible.

That realization sparked a question:
What if we could help organizations truly maximize the depth and breadth of their automation capabilities, strategically and systematically?

That question became a Mission..

They say QA, precision, and automation are in my DNA. For me, it's simple:
 âµ If you do something once, do it manually.
 âµ If you do it more than once, find a way to automate it and let your teams focus on bigger goals.

Over the past year, my team and I have delved deep into industry landscapes and technology ecosystems, including #ERP, #CRM, #HCM, #SCM, #Mobile, #Web, #ThickClients, #CustomApplications, and beyond. From this, we've developed a value-driven framework that brings standardized, scalable practices to Quality Assurance and Test Automation, so companies can get the most out of the tools they've invested in.

And today, life truly comes full circle.

Iâ€™m proud to share that Total Shift Left is entering into a partnership with Leapwork; the very company where this incredible journey began nearly seven years ago.

It feels incredibly meaningful to be able to build upon the foundation we laid together. I remain deeply grateful to the founders, Christian Frederiksen and Claus Topholt, and to colleagues like Tayyab, Praveen, and so many others who shaped this journey with their support, trust, and collaboration.

Every experience, every success, every challenge, contributed to the leader Iâ€™ve become. And for that, Iâ€™m sincerely thankful.

Together, weâ€™ve already built something remarkable. I believe this partnership will take it even further.

Looking forward to reconnecting with you all and building whatâ€™s next, together!

With love,
Rishi

#QualityAssurance #Leapwork #Partnership #Growth #TestAutomation #DigitalTransformation #ProfessionalServices

content:
The Manual Tester to Automation Engineer Career Path

Transitioning from manual tester to automation engineer is a strategic career move that many professionals in the software testing industry aspire to make. As technology continues to evolve at a rapid pace, the demand for automation testing skills is increasing. 

The Current Landscape of Software Testing: Manual vs. Automation

In today's software testing landscape, a significant shift towards automation is evident. While manual testing remains essential for certain scenarios requiring human judgment, automation testing offers numerous benefits in terms of efficiency, accuracy, and scalability. 

Essential Skills and Technologies for Aspiring Automation Engineers

Transitioning from a manual tester to an automation engineer requires a solid foundation in key skills and technologies. Proficiency in programming languages such as Java, Python, or JavaScript is essential for developing automation scripts. Familiarity with automation tools like Selenium, Appium, or JUnit will be crucial in implementing robust test cases. 

Benefits of Transitioning from Manual Testing to Automation Engineering

Transitioning from manual testing to automation engineering brings a myriad of benefits. Automation allows for faster and more efficient testing, resulting in quicker release cycles and improved product quality. With automation, repetitive test cases can be executed seamlessly, freeing up time for manual testers to focus on more strategic testing efforts. 


Common Challenges Faced in the Transition and Strategies to Overcome Them

As you embark on the journey from manual testing to automation engineering, you may encounter challenges such as a steep learning curve in mastering automation tools and frameworks, adapting to scripting languages, and ensuring effective test coverage. To tackle these hurdles, consider investing in comprehensive training programs, hands-on practice sessions, and mentorship opportunities. 

Training and Certification Options for Automation Engineers

To solidify your skills as you transition from manual testing to automation engineering, consider enrolling in reputable training programs and pursuing relevant certifications. Look for courses that focus on popular automation tools like Selenium, Appium, or Robot Framework. These programs will provide you with in-depth knowledge and hands-on experience to excel in automation testing. 

Embracing the Future of Software Testing through Automation

In conclusion, transitioning from manual testing to automation engineering is a strategic move that aligns with the ever-evolving landscape of software testing. By investing in relevant training programs and certifications, you equip yourself with the necessary skills and knowledge to thrive in automation testing.

content:
7 months agoâ€¦ same hustle, very different mindset.
I was pitching AI with perfect decks and getting ghosted every time.

The mistake that cost me my first 3 potential clients (and how it made me a better entrepreneur) 

My presentations were perfect.
My technology was advanced.
My features were impressive. 

But I kept hearing the same response:
"It sounds great, but we need to think about it."
Translation: "No, thanks." 

After losing my third potential client, I realized my mistake:
I was selling features, not outcomes.
I was talking about AI, not about their problems.
I was focused on technology, not transformation.

So I changed everything: Instead of: "Our AI chatbot has natural language processing"
I started saying: "You'll save 10 hours weekly on phone calls"

Instead of: "We use machine learning algorithms"
I started saying: "Your no-shows will drop by 30%"

Instead of: "Our system integrates with multiple platforms"
I started saying: "Your staff will love how easy this makes their job"

The result? My next 5 pitches resulted in 3 pilot programs. The lesson? 

People don't buy features. They buy better futures. 
They don't want technology. They want transformation. 
They don't care how it works. They care that it works. 

Sometimes our biggest failures teach us our most valuable lessons. What's a mistake that made you better at what you do? Share below ğŸ‘‡

Generative AI isnâ€™t coming for your job.

	â€¢	Programming now takes 33 minutes instead of 129
	â€¢	Technology design is down to 39 minutes from 142

This is a wake up call : Itâ€™s not just junior or repetitive roles being impacted. Itâ€™s knowledge work, decision-making, and leadership.

	â€¢	Planning, reporting, or strategic analysis

	â€¢	Presentations, coordination, or training

Youâ€™re not adjacent to the change. Youâ€™re right in the middle of it.

The good news: AI wonâ€™t replace you. But it will replace the slower, more manual version of you â€” the one who still starts everything from scratch.

What this means:
	â€¢	Learn to prompt effectively

	â€¢	Focus on the kind of thinking and collaboration AI canâ€™t replicate

Because the time AI saves is time your business will soon expect you to already have.

content:
We often talk about the cloud in terms of infrastructure, agility, or scale.
But what if we looked at it through a financial lens?
When I started viewing cloud transformation not as a tech migration but as a shift from CAPEX to OPEX, the implications became much clearer â€” and much more strategic.
This change isn't just about servers and storage â€” it's about:
Moving from a heavy upfront investment to a flexible, usage-based cost
Replacing depreciation schedules with real-time expense tracking
Preserving cash flow and improving financial agility
Rethinking ROI, EBITDA impact, and asset-light growth strategies
In my latest post, I explore what this means for finance leaders, with a practical side-by-side example of how on-prem vs. cloud plays out in financial statements.
Itâ€™s time we stop treating digital transformation as "just an IT decision."
 Itâ€™s a capital allocation decision. A risk strategy. A balance sheet strategy.

content:
When a â‚¬100 Million SAP Implementation Goes Wrong: Lessons from LeasePlan's Digital Transformation Failure.
What happens when you try to consolidate 35 legacy systems across 32 countries into a single SAP platform?
If you're LeasePlan, you write off â‚¬100 million, cancel your IPO, and eventually get acquired.
Their 2016-2019 SAP S/4HANA implementation became one of Europe's largest ERP failures. Here's what went wrong and what we can learn:
The Perfect Storm:
ğŸŒ 32 countries, each with unique processes built over decades
ğŸ’» 35 different IT systems trying to become one
â° "Extremely aggressive" timeline (ignoring that similar projects took 7 years)
ğŸš€ Attempting digital transformation while disrupting their own industry
Key Failure Points:
Technical Mismatch: S/4HANA's rigid architecture couldn't handle fleet management's unique requirements
Big Bang Approach: No phased rollout, no safety net
Organizational Resistance: Underestimated the human challenge of changing how 6,600 employees work
Governance Gaps: Too much control given to system integrators, too little internal oversight
The Expensive Lessons: âœ… Industry fit matters - not every business suits monolithic ERP platforms âœ… Phased implementations reduce risk exponentially âœ… Change management isn't secondary - it's often THE critical factor âœ… Past failures (yours and others') are data, not just stories
The Silver Lining: LeasePlan pivoted to a modular "best-of-breed" architecture, combining SAP (limited scope), Salesforce, and Pega. This flexible approach succeeded where the monolithic strategy failed.
The broader lesson? Digital transformation isn't about forcing your business into a one-size-fits-all solution. It's about finding technology that enhances your unique strengths while respecting your operational reality.
What's your experience with large-scale ERP implementations? Have you seen similar patterns?

Securing Industrial Networks: Integrating PRP and VLANs for Advanced ICS Cybersecurity
Published: Nov 22, 2023. Credits: Rodrigo Augusto 
In the age of digital transformation, Industrial Control Systems (ICS) are increasingly interconnected, making cybersecurity a paramount concern. Cyber threats in ICS not only risk data breaches but can also lead to operational disruptions with potentially catastrophic consequences. Two technologies stand out in bolstering ICS cybersecurity: Parallel Redundancy Protocol (PRP) and Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs). This blog post delves into how PRP and VLANs can be pivotal in fortifying an ICS cybersecurity network, including a case study demonstrating their practical application.

In a board meeting last week, another baord member and investor asked:

Fair question. But also kind of like asking, â€œWhatâ€™s your eating strategy?â€
You know you need it. You just donâ€™t really know what it meansâ€”or where to start.
Hereâ€™s the simple truth:
 AI isnâ€™t a strategy. Itâ€™s a tool.
 And like any tool, itâ€™s only useful if it removes friction from your business.
Thatâ€™s the lens every founder should be using:
Where are we wasting time, energy, or moneyâ€¦
 â€¦and how could AI reduce or eliminate that?
Start with use cases like:
â€“ Replacing repetitive tasks that eat up your teamâ€™s day
 â€“ Predicting customer churn or product demand better than your gut
 â€“ Automating insights from messy spreadsheets no one wants to touch
 â€“ Giving your sales team intel that actually shortens the cycle
AI doesnâ€™t have to be some huge platform rollout or 12-month roadmap.
 Sometimes itâ€™s just plugging into a tool that makes your ops team 20% faster this week.
Hereâ€™s how to frame your thinking:
What decisions do we make every week that are slow, painful, or inconsistent?

You donâ€™t need an AI strategy.

 It causes productivity loss. A Forrester study found  \$1.5Mâ€“\$3M lost per 1,000 employees annually due to IT delays â€” mostly from waiting on tickets

### âš™ï¸ How agentic AI transforms service delivery:

Acts as an autonomous agent â€” not just answering but resolving issues.

 Prevents incidents before users even report them.
Elevates IT teams to focus on designing, improving, and governing automationâ€” not chasing tickets.

1,000 Miles, 5 Cities, and One Message: The Future of Work Is Already Here!

Last week I clocked up nearly 1,000 miles across the UK, speaking to some of the UKâ€™s most dynamic and forward-thinking universities, colleges and businesses.

And wherever I presented, one message came through loud and clear:

Weâ€™re not preparing for the future of work anymore. Weâ€™re already in it.
In every session, I explored three of the most urgent and disruptive trends reshaping the workplace:

* AI at Work â€“ No longer a â€˜next big thingâ€™, AI is already transforming hiring, onboarding, client servicing, compliance, and productivity. The key challenge? Moving beyond experimentation and embedding it into core business processes.

* The Multigenerational Workforce â€“ For the first time in history, four generations are working side by side. Soon, itâ€™ll be five. Navigating this multigenerational landscape requires new leadership skills, inclusive cultures, and a fresh approach to communication and collaboration.

* The Attention Crisis â€“ In an always-on world, attention is now the most valuable â€“ and scarce - asset. Whether itâ€™s your workforce, your customers, or your leadership team, the ability to focus, filter, and think deeply is fast becoming the new competitive advantage.

These arenâ€™t future trends â€” theyâ€™re todayâ€™s workplace imperatives. The organisations that thrive will be those willing to adapt, rethink legacy models, and invest in people as much as in tech.

Itâ€™s a privilege to work with such forward thinking organisations and to be able to help them build resilient, human-centred, future-ready cultures.

In the months ahead, Iâ€™ll be continuing this conversation with audiences in the UK, Europe, USA, and Australia â€” helping leaders and teams unlock the skills, mindsets, and strategies needed to thrive in the new world of work.

ğŸ’¡ Why a SAP CoE is crucial for your digital transformation:

One of the main reasons why SAP transformation initiatives fail or donâ€™t meet expectations, is a lack of alignment between business and IT. To bridge this gap, SAP recommends to establish a SAP CoE ğŸ‘‰ Center of Expertise.

A well-functioning SAP CoE is characterized by consolidating SAP skills and knowledge from business and IT into a core team. This allows to generate measurable business value through sustainable and strong collaboration across the enterprise.

Serving as a central hub for all SAP-related activities across business and IT, the SAP CoE should play a pivotal role in any SAP customer organisation. However, operationalising a SAP CoE requires a clear strategy, providing identity and guidelines for the entire SAP community.

Beyond organisational aspects such as decision processes, roles and responsibilities and governance, a SAP CoE should spearhead innovation and improvements. This includes pro-active upskilling with regard to e.g. SAP Activate and Integrated Toolchain but as well AI Adoption to avoid being trapped in outdated patterns of thought.

What are your experiences with SAP CoE organisations? Which key success criteria do you believe are essential to maximise the potential of your internal SAP organisation?

content:
Ethiopia is about to introduce a 15% tax on income earned from social media platforms such as YouTube, TikTok, and others.

I believe this is a positive and timely step to help boost government revenue from the fast-growing digital economy.

However, for this policy to be fair, effective, and enforceable, several important questions need to be addressed:

1ï¸âƒ£ Will the tax declaration process rely entirely on voluntary self-reporting by content creators?

2ï¸âƒ£ Or will social media platforms be required to share detailed data (e.g., who earns income, how much they earn) directly with the tax authority?

3ï¸âƒ£ Will financial service providers and payment processors who handle these payouts also be obliged to report this income?

4ï¸âƒ£ How will this new tax policy align with existing privacy policies of platforms and payment facilitators?

5ï¸âƒ£ What measures will be taken against social media users who incite violence, spread false information, or evade taxes?

6ï¸âƒ£ How will the tax authority distinguish between hobbyists or very small creators and those who generate substantial income?

7ï¸âƒ£ Will there be a minimum income threshold before the tax applies, to avoid overburdening micro or part-time creators?

8ï¸âƒ£ How will taxation apply to Ethiopian creators who are paid through foreign bank accounts or third-party services outside the country?

9ï¸âƒ£ Is there a plan to build digital literacy and tax awareness so creators fully understand their obligations and rights?

ğŸ”Ÿ How will the government ensure that this policy encourages compliance rather than driving creators into informal or underground channels?

These are critical questions to address so this ambitious policy can succeed in practiceâ€”and support Ethiopiaâ€™s broader digital transformation.

What are your thoughts?ğŸ¤”

Iâ€™d love to hear different perspectives on how this might affect creators, businesses, and the digital economy as a whole.

#Ethiopia #DigitalEconomy #TaxPolicy #SocialMediaIncome #Innovation

Ulli Waltinger and I had the pleasure of speaking with Judith about how purpose is not just a buzzword â€“ but the heartbeat of personal growth, leadership, and AI-driven transformation.

#Leadership in the Age of AI: Judith described modern leadership as anchored in kindness, courage, and curiosity. In a fast-changing world, these human values matter more than ever.

Time to say goodbye â€” to two chapters at once.
After 5 visionary and exciting years, my time with the The TMRW Foundation Foundation has come to an end.
This departure also marks a quiet farewell to something deeply personal: neulandherzer â€” the agency I co-founded over more than two decades, pouring into it my heart, passion, vision, and entrepreneurial spirit.
In 2020, we integrated neulandherzer into TMRW with the bold vision of driving the next #digitalrevolution â€” from #Web3 and #Web4 to #AI.
We began as an in-house agency and later evolved into TMRWâ€™s global marketing department under my care.
There was never a proper farewell to neulandherzer â€” no final post, no celebration of what we had built. We were already deep in the next phase. 
Perhaps that time is now.

Iâ€™m truly thankful to RenÃ© Herzer, Jens Jahn, and Mitch for an extraordinary journey filled with unforgettable highlights. Your trust and loyalty meant the world to me.
To the many fantastic colleagues â€” some for decades, like Brian Bray, Robert Lange, Aldona Kwiatkowski, Krystian Bandzimiera, Lutz Wille â€” thanks to all for helping shape #neulandherzer into what it became.
We were also fortunate to work with incredible clients starting with our founding client Mercedes-Benz.
Sven Doerrenbaecher, SÃ¶ren Kiss, Oliver Nolte, Andreas Vill the early years; later Thilo Wessel, Martin Friedrich, Julia Hofmann, Gesina Schwengers, Christiane, Theresa Kraus, Natanael Sijanta, Karsten Mayer and many more.

A heartfelt thanks to Cevat Yerli for his trust and 5 exiting years â€” and to amazing colleagues like Stefanie Palomino, Carsten Fillinger, Ben Kunze, Patrick Wienecke, Rob Black, Felix Zeltner, Can Ozturkeri, Shahzad Khan, Serhat Bekdemir, Roman Wissner â€” we started something bold and Game-changing. Stay tuned!

To everyone who was part of #neulandherzer, our clients who believed in us, our brilliant partners and peers, to those who joined me at #TMRW to keep building, and finally my wife Shirin Neuland â€” without her, I could not have managed. Thank you! â¤ï¸

content:
ğŸ‰ 30 Years of Deutsche Telekom! ğŸ‰

500 guests, classical and modern music, sports, politics, two grand pianos (in Bonn and Hamburg) coming together for a piece of music, and an elephant. Yesterday, we kicked off the celebrations for the 30th anniversary of Telekom with a festive event. We celebrated ourselves, and we were also celebrated a little: 200,000 Telekom employees worldwide.

Who would have thought that the authority called Telekom would once become a modern company? Growing from 37 million to over 300 million customers worldwide? Increasing revenue from 34 billion to 116 billion euros? And rising from number six to the most valuable telecom company in Europe?

Our journey has been one of transformation and design. It has been about decision-making and action. But above all, it has been about people. Like Ron Sommer, who visionary opened up new markets. Or Kai-Uwe Ricke, who took Telekom out of debt and made new investments possible. Or my friend RenÃ© Obermann, who, like no one else, put our customers at the center of our operations. Most importantly, it has been the many Telekom employees who are with us today or who once were. Those who never gave up. Those who continually reinvented themselves and our company, even in the face of headwinds. Change has also left wounds. That is part of our history.

Birthdays certainly evoke nostalgia and reflection. But not reflection that keeps us stagnant. Instead, reflection that serves as motivation. We, too, must reinvent Telekom every day. AI represents a significant revolution. If we use it wisely, we will become even more efficient, customer-oriented, and faster. Hopefully: unbeatable.

My highlight yesterday was the unveiling of the "Gran elephant dret" by Miquel BarcelÃ³. It symbolically represents what Telekom stands for: It is no longer "gray and sluggish." Instead, it is colorful and agile, curious and playful. The elephant that now stands in front of the Telekom headquarters should remind us to "Think again!" It embodies the power of change and the courage to continually reinvent the future. Those who understand the art of making the impossible possible can also achieve remarkable feats.

Thank you to our guests, the Beethoven Orchestra with Dirk Kaftan, Walter Smerling from the Kunst und Kultur Foundation, Mayor Katja DÃ¶rner, Prime Minister (NRW) Hendrik WÃ¼st, Digital Minister Karsten Wildberger, Minister Nathanael Liminski, Philipp Schindera , and everyone who contributed to the success of our festive event.

The "T" in the Deutsche Telekom logo will also continue to stand for transformation and technology, but also for trust and teamwork. And recently also for TÃ¶rrÃ¶Ã¶Ã¶!

#DeutscheTelekom #30Years #Innovation #Transformation #ConnectingYourWorld

Itâ€™s wild how many AI recruiting tools are built by people who have never recruited a day in their life. Meanwhile, the people actually doing the work are stuck duct-taping tools together with no influence over what gets built or bought.

Most recruiters donâ€™t want full automation.
We want flexibility. Control. A system that adapts to how we work, not the other way around.

Iâ€™ve been exploring a platform idea that gives recruiters the power to create their own tools without engineering bottlenecks.

What if you could spin up your own sourcing workflows, interview reminders, or candidate scoring triggers?

Curious what you all think. Would you use something like that? Or would it just feel like one more thing to figure out?

In a world racing toward automation, many feel left behind; not because theyâ€™re incapable, but because the system values speed over wisdom, youth over experience, and profit over people. Whether you're a seasoned professional, a curious leader, or someone navigating your next move, this isn't just a read; it's a recalibration.

content:
Happy Friday! We havenâ€™t gotten approval to disclose the full video yet, but I wanted to highlight our partners at ATI Industrial Automation. This snippet shows how we integrated their automatic tool changers on a #FANUC R-1000iA/80H arm, which allow the robot to swap between adjustable 6-pack and 12-pack tooling without the need for operator involvement. We use a KEYENCE CORPORATION LJ-X8000 laser scanner to provide internal case dimensions and distances between caps and send that information back to the PLC in real time. The robot then picks up the appropriate tool and adjusts to fit the pattern of the scanned case - all fully automated. This was the first machine weâ€™ve designed that wasnâ€™t recipe based - but an â€œon demandâ€ set up due to the number of sizes that could be run. Youâ€™ll see the finished video if/when I can release it, but kudos to our team for thinking outside the box on this application!

#hamrick #robotics #uncasing

What if a robotic bowling arm really existed?

No spotlight, no nerves â€” just perfect throws every time. Imagine having a machine built to help us push past our limits.

A robotic bowling arm could change the way we train. Made for precise and consistent performance, it could repeat thousands of throws exactly the same way  something we canâ€™t do on our own.

We could test different speeds, spins, and release angles without wasting a single throw or waiting for perfect lane conditions.

And it wouldnâ€™t stop at practice. We could study the mechanics of a perfect throw, check how the ball behaves on different oil patterns, and create smarter training plans based on real data.

For example, we could repeat the same hook shot 20,000 times with zero variation and sharpen our form without the guesswork.

This kind of tech wouldnâ€™t replace our effort. It would just remove the guesswork so we can train smarter and get even better.

What skills could we master if every practice gave us perfect feedback?

Could a machine like this take us to levels we havenâ€™t even imagined?

content:
The gap between sophisticated business intelligence tools and actual organizational success lies in workforce capability rather than technology limitations. Data literacyâ€”the ability to read, interpret, analyze, and communicate with data effectivelyâ€”has become a critical competency that separates thriving organizations from those struggling to extract value from their analytics investments. Building a data-literate workforce requires more than technical training; it demands cultural transformation that values evidence-based decision making, critical thinking about data quality and bias, and the confidence to translate raw information into actionable business insights. Organizations that invest in comprehensive data literacy programs, combining hands-on learning experiences with sustainable support systems, create competitive advantages through faster decision-making, improved accuracy in forecasting, and enhanced ability to identify optimization opportunities. As AI and automation make data more accessible, the human element becomes even more crucialâ€”not just for operating BI tools, but for asking the right questions, challenging assumptions, and ensuring that data-driven insights translate into meaningful business outcomes that drive growth and innovation.

content:
What Business Intelligence is (and what it definitely isnâ€™t)

â€œHey, youâ€™re the Developer, can you make me a dashboard?â€

Sure...

But first, can we talk about what you want to see? why it matters? where the data resides? how clean it is? which KPIs we trust? and what decisions youâ€™re trying to make???

Because Business Intelligence isnâ€™t just dashboardsâ€¦ Itâ€™s decisionsâ€¦.

Indeed.. Power BI is great.. I use it every dayâ€¦
But itâ€™s just the presentation!!!

The real BI work happens before anyone even opens the toolâ€¦

Hereâ€™s what BI actually involves:
- Understanding the business question.. not just the data.
- Cleaning messy data that wasnâ€™t made for reporting (but somehow still exists)..
- Building logic to make things add up..
- Choosing the right metrics, not just the available ones.
- Telling a story that leads to action, not confusionâ€¦

Some techniques are used like:
- Data modeling (to make things make sense)..
- Forecasting (to stop guessing)..
- Segmentation (to stop generalizing)..
- Root cause analysis (to stop blaming the developers)..

So yes, I can make you a dashboardâ€¦
But what I really do is help you make smarter decisions, backed by data that tells the truth, and not just the trendâ€¦

Again.. BI is not about pretty charts... Itâ€™s about CLARITY... INSIGHTS... IMPACT...

And sometimes, that starts with reminding people:
Itâ€™s called Business Intelligence for a reason, and not Chart Intelligenceâ€¦

Business Intel Eng 2M Intern - Amazon, India ::

As a BIE - Intern on the team, you will enable effective decision making by retrieving and aggregating data from multiple sources and triangulating the data points/ metrics into reports and actionable format. Your ownership of the scoping and design of new metrics and enhancement of existing ones will help support the future state of business processes and ensure sustainability. You will communicate analysis and insights to stakeholders and business leaders, both verbally and in writing. These analytics and metrics will help ensure we are focused on whatâ€™s important, enable clarity and focus, and delight our customers.

Basic Qualifications

* Bachelorâ€™s degree in Computer Science, Mathematics, Statistics, Operations Research
* Proficiency in SQL and in one or more programming language â€“ Python, Scala, Ruby and Java.
* Knowledge of data management fundamentals, data storage principles, ETL, Data Modeling, and Data Architecture.
* Knowledge on using business intelligence reporting tools â€“ Tableau/QuickSight/Looker
* Familiar with theory and practice of information retrieval, relevance, Statistics, and data mining and skilled at data visualization and presentation.
* Excellent problem solving skills, combined with the ability to present your findings/insights clearly and compellingly in both verbal and written form.

What if the real disruption in manufacturing isnâ€™t coming from AI, cloud, or automation... but from the uncomfortable realization that weâ€™ve been investing in all the wrong things?

According to Deloitteâ€™s 2025 Smart Manufacturing Survey, manufacturers are pouring billions into tech. ğŸ•ğŸ–% are allocating over ğŸğŸ% of their improvement budgets to smart manufacturing. ğŸ’ğŸ”% are prioritizing process automation. 
The intent is clear. 
The excitement is real. 

Butâ€¦. I would argue ğ°ğâ€™ğ«ğ ğ¬ğ­ğ¢ğ¥ğ¥ ğ§ğ¨ğ­ ğ«ğğšğğ²..
Not in our culture. 
Not in our org structures. 
Not in how we prepare our people.

The data exposes the gap. Human capital is the least mature capability in the smart manufacturing stack. Only ğŸ’ğŸ–% of companies have a training and adoption standard. Yet itâ€™s the number one area they say they want to improve. And while ğŸ–ğŸ“% believe smart manufacturing will attract new talent, more than a third say their biggest human capital concern is simply adapting workers to the factory of the future.

We like the sound of digital transformation as long as it doesn't slow us down. We like the optics of AI as long as we don't have to redesign how we work. We like talking about the workforce of the future as long as we donâ€™t have to train the one we already have.

So yes, investment is rising. But if we donâ€™t confront the outdated systems and assumptions holding us back, all weâ€™re doing is layering expensive tech on fragile foundations.

The biggest barrier to smart manufacturing isnâ€™t budget, technology, or even talent.

Itâ€™s us.

content:
From Autonomy to Accountability â€“ Where AI Strategy Really Begins

We recently explored how agentic AI is no longer a future concept, itâ€™s already reshaping operations, workflows, and decision-making across sectors.

We discussed how intelligent systems are now capable of acting autonomously, streamlining functions end-to-end, and creating space for people to do higher-value work.

But autonomy brings a new question to the surface:
Who owns the strategy behind it? From what AI can do to how it should be led.
Because no matter how advanced the technology becomes, its value will still hinge on leadership decisions:
 - Where is AI best applied to support business growth?
 - What level of oversight is needed across functions?
 - Who is accountable for its outcomesâ€”when no human touched the process?

This isnâ€™t about controlling AI. Itâ€™s about owning the strategic direction.

AI is now influencing how organisations compete, how value is delivered to customers, and how business models evolve. It belongs in executive conversations and not just tech working groups.

Strong leadership will define whether AI becomes an enabler of smart growth or a scattered series of half-deployed tools.

So letâ€™s start with a foundational prompt:
 - Who leads the AI agenda in your organisation and is it tied directly to business strategy or still viewed as an operational initiative?

#AILeadership #StrategicTechnology #AIinBusiness #ExecutiveThinking #DigitalStrategy #TransformationLeadership #CIUK #FutureOfWork #BoardroomAI #Businessgrowth

AI agents are everywhere â€” but few can explain what they actually do or why they matter.
Hereâ€™s a practical breakdown to help you cut through the buzz. ğŸ‘‡
ğŸ§  What is an AI Agent?
 Think of it as an intelligent digital teammate â€” one that can think, plan, act, and improve with each task.
AI agents follow a continuous loop:
 1ï¸âƒ£ Think â€“ Analyze data and context
 2ï¸âƒ£ Plan â€“ Strategize how to achieve a goal
 3ï¸âƒ£ Act â€“ Execute actions via tools, APIs, or interfaces
 4ï¸âƒ£ Reflect â€“ Learn from results and adapt
The magic? They donâ€™t just follow instructions â€” they optimize over time.
ğŸ’¡ Not all agents are built the same. Like a strong team, variety drives impact:
 â–ªï¸ Reflex Agents â€“ React instantly based on rules
 â–ªï¸ Model-Based â€“ Use memory to make informed decisions
 â–ªï¸ Goal-Based â€“ Operate with outcomes in mind
 â–ªï¸ Utility-Based â€“ Evaluate options and trade-offs
 â–ªï¸ Learning Agents â€“ Continuously evolve
You donâ€™t scale with just one type of agent â€” you build a system.
ğŸ—ï¸ How theyâ€™re structured matters too:
 â–ªï¸ Single Agent Systems â€“ Focused on one task
 â–ªï¸ Multi-Agent Systems â€“ Agents coordinate to solve complex problems
The real opportunity? Designing agent ecosystems that align with your workflows, securely and responsibly.
AI agents arenâ€™t the future â€” theyâ€™re already here.
 The challenge is no longer â€œwhat can they do?â€ â€” but how well can we integrate them into the way we work.

content:
Most business leaders don't realize this soon enough: AI won't replace you. But someone using AI will.

At Hemraj Group, we have been exploring oppurtunities and possibilitites with AI, while questioning...

Every manual process. Every analysis that takes months. Every decision requiring endless back-and-forth.

Yes, we were getting things done, but we were working harder, not smarter. And then came the shift.  

I asked myself: What if we could automate 80% of our routine tasks?

That uncomfortable question forced me to rethink everything.

We are planning to put real AI integration in place:
âœ… Automating our inventory forecasting = saving hours weekly.
âœ… Using AI for contract analysis = reducing review time by 60%.
âœ… Implementing chatbots for customer queries = 24/7 support without burnout.
âœ… Using AI for market research = insights in minutes, not days.

The goal isn't to replace people, it is to empower them.

Because smart leaders don't fear AI. They harness it to focus on what humans do best: strategy, creativity, and relationships.

To fellow business owners: The future isn't about competing with AI.

It's about collaborating with it, while you focus on the vision that only human leaders can provide.

What are your thoughts? Let me know in the comments.

Most â€œ#Innovationâ€ Is Just Imitation in Disguise.

Every week, I see companies slap #AI, #Web3, or some shiny tool onto their strategy, then call it a breakthrough.

Whenever I evaluate a new #technology or campaign, I ask #3 #questions that save time, budget, and a lot of regret later:

1ï¸âƒ£ What behavior are we changing?
Be specific:
â€“ Faster buying
â€“ More trust
â€“ Higher #retention

If you canâ€™t name it, itâ€™s just noise.

2ï¸âƒ£ What proof do we have?
â€“ Has this worked in our #market?
â€“ Where did it fail?
â€“ Are we testing or copying?

3ï¸âƒ£ What does success mean?
Define impact:
â€“ Adoption
â€“ Revenue
â€“ Lower #CAC
â€“ Higher #LTV

Bottom line:
#Innovation isnâ€™t about being first. Itâ€™s about being right, for your customer and your #business.

Next time you feel pressure to jump on the next big thing, step back.
-Ask better #questions.
-Build with #intention, not impulse.

content:
When I started in business over 10 years ago, I was obsessed with doing things right from the start.

That meant researching everything thoroughly.

Testing software. Comparing systems. Sitting down with people. Asking questions. Doing trials.

I wanted to be absolutely sure before pulling the trigger on a decision.

And for the most part, that mindset served me well.

But lately, Iâ€™ve started to question it - especially when it comes to software, tech, and AI.

The pace of change now is relentless.

Businesses that are testing early - the ones building, breaking, learning, adjusting - theyâ€™re the ones who will stay relevant.

Perfection from the start might have been a strength once.

But now?

Speed, iteration, and adaptability win.

Iâ€™m learning to lean into that.

Fast tests. Small bets. Real-world feedback.

Because done beats perfect - especially in a world moving this fast.

#entrepreneurship #aiinbusiness #innovationmindset #businessgrowth

Process Control Engineering is where theory meets application. From feedback loops, PID controllers, and transfer functions, to dynamic modeling of systems â€” it's all about ensuring that industrial processes run smoothly, reliable , safely, and efficiently.

content:
McDonald's trusted an AI chatbot with 64 million job applications. Hackers needed just six keystrokes to access them all.

â¡ï¸ I've seen plenty of security failures, but this one takes the McFlurry. Security researchers just exposed how McDonald's AI hiring platform left millions of job seekers' data vulnerableâ€”protected by a password that would embarrass a middle schooler: '123456'.

â¡ï¸ The platform, built by Paradox.ai, features an AI chatbot named Olivia that screens applicants through McHire.com. Researchers Ian Carroll and Sam Curry discovered they could access 64 million application records simply by guessing administrator credentials. 

â¡ï¸ No multifactor authentication. No security checks. Just instant access to names, emails, phone numbersâ€”everything applicants shared while desperately trying to explain their job experience to a confused chatbot.

â¡ï¸ The breach reveals a darker pattern in our rush to automate everything. We're handing over sensitive human moments, like job applications, to AI systems secured with less care than your Netflix account.This incident crystallizes three uncomfortable truths about our AI-powered future:

ğŸ‘‰ Companies deploy AI for efficiency but forget basic security fundamentals
ğŸ‘‰ The most vulnerable data often belongs to those seeking entry-level work
ğŸ‘‰ Human oversight remains critical when machines handle human dignity

â“ When we delegate human processes to machines, we inherit new responsibilities, not shed them.  As we accelerate toward AI-mediated everything, here's my question: Should companies be required to match their security investment to their automation ambitions?

Read the full article on WIRED: https://lnkd.in/g8sB7xnT

2025 prediction: Half of traditional accounting firms will be forced to merge, sell, or close within 3 years.

I'm already seeing it happen as I scope out firms on https://lnkd.in/g5yTNaDB.

Firms with 60%+ labor costs can't compete with automated firms charging less and delivering faster results.

Last quarter, one firm couldn't get her clients organized enough to sell her business because it was too manual. It was unsellable.

Meanwhile, smaller tech-savvy firms are landing their biggest clients ever.

The math is brutal:
Traditional firm: 65% labor costs, 15% margins, 55-hour weeks for partners Automated firm: 35% labor costs, 40%+ margins, flexibility and reasonable hours.

This isn't about technology disruption anymore.

It's about business model evolution.

The firms that embrace automation now will acquire the assets of the ones that resist.

We're not in the accounting business. We're in the efficiency business.

The market is already rewarding firms that can deliver faster, better, and more profitably.

What are you seeing in your market? Are the most efficient firms starting to dominate?

content:
The future of Business Intelligence is going to look a lot like observability. 

Dashboards are awesome. But what if they were significantly more dynamic? What if we could instrument our *businesses* like we currently instrument distributed systems?

What if every team could ask ad hoc questions in natural language? Trace data issues across sources, set up alerts on KPIs, etc? 

That would mean that Analytics shifts from a passive to an active workflow. From polling to streaming. From â€œpull when neededâ€ to â€œpush when relevant.â€

It means you'll be able to debug business performance in the same way you debug production incidents.

It means your company will operate at a much higher level.

This is the future we're building at Basedash.

article.title: MCP in Business Intelligence: Top Use Cases and Key Security Risks
article.subtitle: Howard Taylor ACA, CA(SA)
article.linkLabel: Open article: MCP in Business Intelligence: Top Use Cases and Key Security Risks by Howard Taylor ACA, CA(SA) â€¢ 11 min read

content:
Why Business Intelligence Fails Without the Business Part

We often focus so much on the "intelligence" the tools, the models, the visuals, that we forget the first word in Business Intelligence is business.
And thatâ€™s where many projects fail.
A technically brilliant dashboard that answers no relevant question, uses undefined metrics, or confuses the end user wonâ€™t drive decisions. It might impress other analysts. But it wonâ€™t create value.
Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned working on BI solutions that move the needle:

âœ… 1. No tool replaces understanding the business problem

 Itâ€™s tempting to start by connecting data and exploring what we can show.
 But without a clear business goal, we build in the dark.
The best BI projects start with conversations, not queries:
What decisions are you trying to support?
Whatâ€™s not working today?
How do you define success?
Only then should we touch Power BI, SQL, or Python.

âœ… 2. Metrics must reflect reality, not just calculation

 KPIs like revenue, churn, and conversion may sound straightforward until you ask three teams how they calculate them.
If the numbers donâ€™t reflect shared definitions, the insights wonâ€™t drive aligned actions.
 Before modeling, validate with stakeholders:
 â€œDoes this formula match your understanding?â€
Clarity builds trust. And trust drives adoption.

âœ… 3. If they canâ€™t read it, they wonâ€™t use it

A dashboard isnâ€™t just a data product. Itâ€™s a communication piece.
If it requires explanation, if the filters are unclear, if the charts overwhelm, people stop using it.
Visual strategy matters. But what matters most is this:
Can the business person answer their question in 10 seconds?
If not, we redesign.

BI without the "business" is just charts.
The role of the analyst isnâ€™t to display data. Itâ€™s to make decisions easier, faster, and more confidently through clarity, relevance, and collaboration.
That starts by listening more than building.
How do you bring the â€œbusinessâ€ into your BI projects?

content:
On #RealEstate & #UrbanDevelopment from Bloomberg:
â€œPersistently high vacancy rates & deep discounts in the US office real estate market are making the case for a reset of central business districts. And Chicago, where a redevelopment campaign for its downtownÂ is just beginning to take shape, may offer its peers a roadmap. Last year, the #UniversityofChicago launched an annual innovation challenge calling on grad students to pitch plans to revive the cityâ€™s core. The most revealing proposals from this yearÂ reimagined futureÂ business districts as notÂ â€˜monocultures of high-density white-collar work,â€™Â (Bloomberg) contributor Zach Mortice reports, butÂ residential destinations that would attract other demographics â€” including artists, young professionals & families with kids. â€¦The era of American downtowns as monocultures of high-density white-collar work appears to be over, & what replaces it stands to be the most significant real estate reset of the post-Covid era. In many ways, business districts are learning to become more urban places, widening their economic bases & learning to become more welcoming to new kinds of people. But to achieve that mix, cities like Chicago will have to unravel much of the last centuryâ€™s urban fabric â€” a redevelopment campaign whose planning & scale are now beginning to take shape.Â A persistent vacancy plight has helped make the Loop â€” which on most weekdays feels like a playground for tourists & a diminished corps of commuters â€” something of a laboratory for this great downtown reinvention. â€¦New research by the Pew Charitable Trust & the global architecture firm Gensler explores the potential for office-to-residential conversions into communal co-living apartments across seven cities, Chicago included. Here, former office buildings are filled w/a ring of micro-scaled sleeping quarters along their perimeter, w/central core of shared kitchens, bathrooms, & social lounges â€” an arrangement recognizable to anyone thatâ€™s every trudged through a college dorm hallway w/shampoo in plastic shower caddy. â€¦The trade-off in private space is affordability, w/rents for each mini-unit ranging from $500 to $1,000 a month. In Chicago, 28% of renters are considered severely cost burdened, paying more than half of their income in rent. â€¦Ideally, downtown neighborhoods will be able to place families with kids & young professionals side-by-side w/complementary sets of amenities attractive to both, like walkable streets, parks & transit infrastructure.Â W/new patterns of work & life well-established, downtowns may lose some prestige as the commercial engines of their cities, but theyâ€™ll have much to gain by looking at themselves as one of many city neighborhoods.â€From an article posted 6/30/25, on Bloomberg CityLab Daily by Zach Mortice â€“ U.S. architecture journalist.
For more #ThoughtsAndObservations about #CityPlanning (Urban, Suburban and Rural) go to https://lnkd.in/ghy95Q3b

Most companies treat digital transformation like a software upgrade. They invest millions in platforms, dashboards, and integrations, but ignore the foundational work that actually makes those tools effective. Without strong data architecture, aligned planning, and a culture ready to adapt, the tech becomes just another layer of complexity.

Real transformation in 2025 is quieter and smarter. It is not about stacking more systems. It is about simplifying how decisions are made, how teams move, and how leaders operate. The companies that win are not the ones shouting about AI or digital maturity. They are the ones designing businesses that run smoother, faster, and with less drag.

This is exactly the shift we focus on at Collectiv. We help business leaders redesign how data, planning, and automation power their business. Not just digitize what is already broken. Because the goal is not to transform. It is to evolve intelligently and scale without burning out your people or drowning in tools.

Digital marketing lost its marketing

Everyoneâ€™s obsessed with tools, hacks, tricks, automations, AI promptsâ€¦

But the basics? Buyer psychology? Real marketing?

No wonder people keep asking if digital marketing is worth it.

I started the same way.
Watched tutorials. Took cheap courses. Ran ads. Did local SEO.
It worked for small, local businesses.

Then a mid-sized cybersecurity firm asked for a strategy.
Instant imposter syndrome.
Because following a workflow isnâ€™t the same as knowing why people buy.

We began landing and keeping big accounts in tough markets because we finally led with strategy, built solid fundamentals, and stopped playing hope-the-template-works.

No software, AI, or growth hack replaces the human part, ever.

content:
Mark Cuban predicts that AI-generated video will have a surprising side effect: more in-person engagement. In a June post on X, Cuban said that as AI video becomes more realistic, people wonâ€™t trust what they see online â€” and will seek out live, face-to-face experiences instead.

He called it the â€œMilli Vanilli effect,â€ referencing the pop duo who lost their careers after it was revealed they had lip-synced their music. Cuban believes AI will soon make digital content so convincing that authenticity will become rare â€” and valuable. â€œWithin the next 3 years,â€ he wrote, â€œthere will be so much AIâ€¦ people wonâ€™t know whatâ€™s real.â€

Tools like Googleâ€™s Veo 3 are accelerating this shift. Veo can generate realistic 8-second videos with synchronized dialogue and facial expressions for less than $2. It's already capable of producing fake interviews, songs, and therapy sessions â€” all AI-generated.

Cuban is bullish on AI's potential. He says tools like ChatGPT and Gemini allow individuals to launch startups without teams. But critics argue that automation often leads to worse jobs and more inequality.

Still, Cuban sees a new era coming â€” one where people value real-life presence more than ever.

content: Tesla is targeting $2.5 billion in annual savings by replacing about 10% of its workforce with Optimus humanoid robots. The company plans to deploy Optimus for repetitive, tedious, or slightly dangerous tasks, particularly within its factories, where the robots are expected to take over roles currently filled by entry-level employees. Each Optimus unit could save Tesla up to $57,550 per year compared to a human worker, and over a five-year period, the total cost of an Optimus robot is estimated at $105,000, which is more than $100,000 less than the equivalent cost of employing an entry-level worker in the U.S.. Tesla aims to produce several thousand Optimus robots in 2025, with production ramping up to 50,000 units in 2026 and potentially reaching 500,000 units by 2029. This large-scale automation initiative is expected to dramatically cut labor costs and boost manufacturing efficiency as Tesla leverages its expertise in vertical integration and real-world AI.

content:
*DevOps engineer Lords Prayer*

"Our Father, who art in the cloud..." This acknowledges the distributed nature of modern infrastructure and the reliance on cloud-based services.
"Hallowed be thy deployments..." This highlights the importance of reliable and repeatable deployments, ensuring that changes are implemented smoothly and without disruption.
"Thy CI/CD pipeline come, thy automation be done..." This emphasizes the reliance on Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery pipelines and the need for automated processes throughout the software development lifecycle.
"Give us this day our daily uptime..." This acknowledges the importance of maintaining system availability and minimizing downtime. 
"And forgive us our failed deploys, as we forgive those who break the build..." This recognizes the inevitability of errors and the need for a culture of learning and forgiveness when things go wrong, coupled with the importance of collaborative code reviews.
"And lead us not into manual deployments, but deliver us from server sprawl..." This highlights the goal of minimizing manual tasks and reducing the complexity of infrastructure management.
"For thine is the infrastructure, the automation, and the glory, forever. Amen." This acknowledges the ultimate responsibility for the infrastructure and the value derived from efficient and automated processes. 
This "prayer" encapsulates the core values of DevOps, emphasizing collaboration, automation, and a focus on delivering value through efficient and reliable processes. It reflects a mindset of continuous improvement and a shared commitment to building and maintaining robust and scalable systems.

â€œThe real power of AI isn't in replacing us; it's in revealing what more weâ€™re capable of.â€ 

It started with a simple realization. The way we make decisions at the enterprise level is changing. Iâ€™ve sat in meetings where the data is not only presented but interpreted. Risks are flagged before we ask. Forecasts adjust in real time. Recommendations arrive with reasoning behind them. It is beyond better software. Itâ€™s agentic and generative AI stepping into the role of #intelligent collaborators. 

ğŸ” A recent example?
One of the well-known enterprises in the manufacturing sector has implemented an #agentic AI system to modernize its maintenance operations. The AI predicted failures before they occurred, auto-initiated spare part procurement, and rerouted field teams based on urgency and proximity.

The impact? A 40% #reduction in downtime, #extended asset lifespan, and significant operational #savings. 

In finance, Iâ€™ve seen these systems uncover patterns we would miss. They manage risk, automate compliance, and improve forecasting with speed and clarity. In healthcare, models are designing personalised treatments, while agentic systems predict how a condition might evolve for each patient. In retail, shelves are restocked before the shortage occurs.

Customers experience interactions tailored to their behaviour, not their purchase history.

What strikes me is the #intelligence and the #freedom it creates. When AI manages repetitive and reactive tasks, people gain time to lead, solve, and innovate. Strategy becomes sharper. Collaboration deepens. Decisions are made with both #insight and intention. 

At Hitachi Systems India, we are not observing this shift from the sidelines. We are shaping it. AI is becoming an integral part of how businesses operate. The future is not what we wait for. It is something we actively build.

I always wanted to write a book about ERP.
But after doing some research, I realized there are already so many well-written books on the subject. How could I possibly compete, even with AI helping me?

So I hit pause.

Then came an idea:
Why not write a mini-book about ERP, targeted to teens?

I set off on this mission, chapter after chapter. But when I reached the final one, a thought crossed my mind:
Will ERP even be around when these teens grow up?

For a moment I hesitated. But then I reminded myself:
ERP is here to stay, at least for the coming decades, though likely with powerful AI layers on top.

So I went ahead and published it. Just the electronic version for now.

content:
For those of us serving business customers, the wave of AI is already rolling in.

From onboarding to support to success planning, vendors are adding new tools, copilots, and agents into the customer experience.

A recent HBR article and a particularly thoughtful comment thread got me thinking more critically about this shift:
ğŸ‘‰ Agentic AI Is Already Changing the Workforce

Itâ€™s tempting to jump ahead to the future of scale. But what if we donâ€™t yet have the foundation right?

Across most organizations, the customer experience spans many teams: Implementation, Customer Success, Support, and sometimes RevOps or Product.

Yet the work itselfâ€”the actual tasks, handoffs, ownershipâ€”is often undocumented, assumed, or siloed.

We often know the outcomes we want:
â€¢ Faster time to value
â€¢ Higher retention
â€¢ Better relationships

But we donâ€™t always know:
â€¢ Who is doing what
â€¢ How work flows (or gets stuck) across teams
â€¢ Where the duplication, delays, or gaps really are

Without that clarity, AI can still be powerful, but it risks adding confusion or scaling misaligned work instead of impact.

What Iâ€™m exploring now is this:
ğŸ‘‰ To make the most of AI, we first need to make the work visible
ğŸ‘‰ And then, reassign it thoughtfully between humans and agents

Over the next few weeks, Iâ€™ll be sharing a series of posts for those working across customer experience, operations, and product enablement.

Weâ€™ll dig into:
â€¢ How to map the real work behind the customer journey, or any workflow tied to experience and outcomes
â€¢ Where agentic AI can meaningfully reduce effort or risk
â€¢ What it means to define roles when agents are part of the team
â€¢ How to evaluate vendors who promise intelligent automation
â€¢ And why your top performers might be your best AI trainers

This isnâ€™t about replacing humans.

Itâ€™s about redesigning the way we work so people and agents can create better outcomes together.

If youâ€™re working at the intersection of customer experience and AI, I hope youâ€™ll follow along and share what youâ€™re seeing too.

Letâ€™s stay clear and intentional as we bring AI into the way we deliver customer experience.


ğŸ’¬ Where do you see opportunities or risks when layering AI into the customer experience?

#CustomerExperience #AIinBusiness #SaaS #WorkflowDesign #FutureOfWork #AgenticAI

content:
I spoke at The Council by Archangel in Austin. It was a last-minute invitation, and I came prepared with notes, frameworks, and a whole game plan. But when I walked into that room, I made a different choice, I stopped talking. I listened. 

Because sometimes, the smartest move in leadership isnâ€™t to speak louder. Itâ€™s to stay quiet long enough to hear what actually matters. 

What I heard in that room, and what Iâ€™ve heard in almost every room full of founders, is this: so many of us are chasing a version of success that was never truly ours to begin with. We build based on borrowed expectations. We market based on what we think others will approve of. We scale businesses that look great from the outside but donâ€™t feel aligned on the inside. 

And if Iâ€™m being real, Iâ€™ve been there too. Iâ€™ve built big companies. Iâ€™ve helped drive billions in traffic. Iâ€™ve hit revenue goals and landed the deals people dream about. But Iâ€™ve also looked around and wondered, â€œWhy doesnâ€™t this feel right?â€ 

The shift for me wasnâ€™t about strategy. It was about honesty. I stopped building to impress. And I started building to feel. Because in a digital world moving at the speed of automation, the real risk isnâ€™t failure, itâ€™s indifference. People donâ€™t remember what was polished and safe. They remember what was real and meaningful. 

So if youâ€™re building something right now, hereâ€™s the question Iâ€™d challenge you to ask: Are you creating from alignment or from expectation? Iâ€™m not here to win the room anymore. Iâ€™m here to change what happens after the room. Letâ€™s build brands people donâ€™t just notice, but actually believe in. 

#Leadership #Entrepreneurship

Learning to Be Gentle with Myself

Iâ€™ve been under the weather for the past two weeks. The kind of sick that makes your body whisper (and sometimes shout), â€œSit down. Be still. Let me work.â€

And in that stillness, Iâ€™ve been reminded how much of me still wants to push even when thereâ€™s nothing left to give.

The emails I want to send.
The videos I want to record.
The projects that feel like theyâ€™re waiting on me to come alive againâ€¦

But this time, I didnâ€™t force it.

This time, I chose gentleness over guilt.
Rest over rushing.
Healing over hustling.

Itâ€™s not easy â€” especially when youâ€™re used to holding so much. But Iâ€™m learning that true power isnâ€™t in how much I can doâ€¦ itâ€™s in how fully I can honor what I need.

And right now, that means grace.
Slowness.
Trusting that nothing good will pass me by just because Iâ€™m healing.

Iâ€™ll be back in full force soon. But even then, Iâ€™ll carry this softness with me.

P.S. If it werenâ€™t for all the automation in my business, I mightâ€™ve tried to run a webinar with a fever. So thank you, workflows â€” yâ€™all really showed up for me. ğŸ¤–ğŸ’›

Enterprise IT explained in 2 mins (without buzzwords)

Imagine youâ€™re running a city.

Email - Thatâ€™s your postal system.
Wi-Fi - Thatâ€™s your public roads.
Laptops - Those are city-issued vehicles.
And servers - Thatâ€™s the infrastructure no one sees but flips out over when it breaks.

Every department - police, parks, sanitation - wants their own tools, platforms, and systems.

Thatâ€™s shadow IT.

Then one day, the city gets hacked.
Someone left the gates open. Password was â€œPassword123.â€

Thatâ€™s your cybersecurity incident.
Now youâ€™re doing a risk assessment while trying not to cry.

You patch it up. Buy five new tools.
Your CFO: â€œWhy do we have 19 IT vendors?â€
You: â€œBecause Karen clicked a PDF.â€

Thatâ€™s security sprawl.

You try to streamline. Centralize systems.
But every upgrade takes 6 months and three committees.

Thatâ€™s governance.

Eventually, you convince everyone to use the same system.
People still complain, but now at least itâ€™s the same complaints.

Thatâ€™s digital transformation.

And just when things are finally calm..

A new exec shows up and says:
â€œWhy donâ€™t we use AI?â€

Thatâ€™s enterprise IT.

Well, what did I miss? Help me add on to this.

Your call doesnâ€™t end when the customer hangs up.

Too many contact centers treat wrap-up time as a race to hit the â€œReadyâ€ button.

Some best practices we recommend:

â€¢ Wrap-up notes should tell a story, not just â€œcall back laterâ€
â€¢ Dispositions should be accurate, not defaulted to the first option on the list
â€¢ Follow-ups should be triggered, not left to memory or post-it notes
â€¢ Hold time and transfers should be logged, not ignored

These small steps make a big difference in coaching, QA, and automation.

If your after-call process is an afterthought, your data will be too.

AI is not a tech upgrade â€” itâ€™s a cultural and strategic shift. Businesses that treat AI as a bolt-on tool risk missing the full potential of what it truly offers: reinventing value creation, decision-making, and customer experiences.
Hereâ€™s a practical 10-step transformation roadmap Iâ€™ve used across real estate, e-commerce, manufacturing, and services â€” scaling operations from traditional to AI-native:

ğŸš€ 1. Reframe Strategy Around AI
Donâ€™t chase shiny tools. Instead, define your â€œAI North Star.â€ Align AI with your core business goals â€” revenue growth, CX, efficiency, innovation.

ğŸš€ 2. Build Digital & Data Infrastructure
AI thrives on clean, connected, real-time data. Break silos, invest in cloud-native architecture, data lakes, and data governance. Data maturity is your first moat.

ğŸš€ 3. Identify High-Impact Use Cases
Pick use cases that hit fast and hard â€” like predictive sales, automated support, AI-driven demand planning, or intelligent CRM. Use complexity vs ROI matrix to prioritize.

ğŸš€ 4. Reskill & Realign Talent
The future workforce isnâ€™t just technical â€” itâ€™s AI-literate. Upskill your teams in prompt engineering, data fluency, GenAI tools, and ethical AI principles. Talent agility is key.

ğŸš€ 5. Form a Cross-Functional AI Task Force
Create a steering unit combining strategy, tech, ops, HR, finance, and legal. Let them co-own the AI roadmap and embed change in workflows.

ğŸš€ 6. Start Small, Scale Fast
Run agile pilots, measure value, gather feedback, then scale. Think of AI adoption as â€œmicro wins, macro shift.â€ Avoid tech theatre; go for measurable transformation.

ğŸš€ 7. Embed AI in Processes & Culture
Redesign operating models to co-pilot with AI. Empower teams to make data-informed decisions. Drive change from the C-suite to the frontlines. Build AI into your DNA.

ğŸš€ 8. Lead with Governance & Ethics
AI without guardrails is a risk multiplier. Establish frameworks for bias mitigation, transparency, and accountability. Responsible AI builds long-term trust.

ğŸš€ 9. Leverage Ecosystem Partnerships
You donâ€™t have to build everything. Collaborate with AI startups, academic labs, and cloud providers. Leverage pre-trained models and AI-as-a-Service tools to move faster.

ğŸš€ 10. Measure. Iterate. Transform Continuously
Transformation is not linear. Build feedback loops. Track KPIs (productivity, CSAT, cost-to-serve). Use insights to refine and scale.

âœ… BOTTOM LINE:
AI transformation is NOT an IT initiative. Itâ€™s a business reinvention journey led by visionary leadership, powered by data, and driven by purpose. Organizations that act now will shape the future â€” not chase it.

ğŸ’¡If you're building AI strategy or transforming a legacy business, letâ€™s exchange insights.

content:
I'm pleased to share that my research paper titled "An Integrated Machine Learning Model for E-Commerce Churn Prediction" has been officially published in the International Journal of Innovative Science and Research Technology (IJISRT).
This work addresses a critical challenge of customer churn in the e-commerce space by developing a hybrid machine learning model that combines boosting with clustering within the CRISP-DM framework, leveraging both classification power and behavioral segmentation.
ğŸ“ˆ Key Achievements:
 âœ… Accuracy: 98.68%
 âœ… Precision: 96.19%
 âœ… Recall: 94.39%
 âœ… F1 Score: 95%
These results demonstrate the effectiveness of combining multiple machine learning techniques to generate deeper customer insights and support proactive retention strategies.
ğŸ’¼ Industry Implications:
 This research provides a practical roadmap for businesses aiming to reduce churn by:
 â€¢ Leveraging customer behavior data
 â€¢ Segmenting users more effectively
 â€¢ Implementing targeted retention actions
 â€¢ Building predictive systems that adapt over time
ğŸ™ğŸ½ Special appreciation goes to my supervisors,
 Prof. Abraham Deme and Ass. Prof. Gideon Bibu of the University of Jos,
 for their invaluable mentorship and support.

-Tested various indexing strategies
-Examined join conditions and data relationships
-Considered hardware solutions like database replicas and materialized views (but these would have sacrificed real-time data)
-Dug deep into PostgreSQL execution plans
-Finally discovered the real culprit: a correlated subquery running 3.5 million times due to inefficient view joins

ğ“ğ¡ğ ğ’ğ¨ğ¥ğ®ğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§: Instead of throwing hardware at the problem, we took a precision approach:
- Replaced expensive view joins with targeted column selection
- Restructured queries to leverage PostgreSQL's optimizer
- Made surgical changes without touching infrastructure

ğ“ğ¡ğ ğ‘ğğ¬ğ®ğ¥ğ­: âœ… 98.8% performance improvement (25s â†’ 0.3s) âœ… 99% reduction in database load âœ… Dashboards that load instantly âœ… Preserved real-time data access

ğŠğğ² ğ“ğšğ¤ğğšğ°ğšğ²: Complex data problems require patience and systematic analysis. Sometimes the biggest wins come from understanding how your database thinks, not just what you're asking it to do.

content:
âœ”ï¸Here is detailed information about the Arduino Uno:

Overview:

The Arduino Uno is a microcontroller board based on the ATmega328P. It is one of the most popular boards in the Arduino family. ideal for beginners and hobbyists.

Pin Diagram Explanation:

1. Digital Pins (0-13): For input/output operations (like reading switches. controlling LEDs).

2. Analog Pins (A0-A5): Read analog sensors like temperature or light.

3. PWM Pins (3.5.6. 9. 10. 11): Provide Pulse Width Modulation for dimming LEDs or controlling motors.

4. TX (1) and RX (0): Used for serial communication.

5. Power Pins:

Vin: Input voltage.

5V/3.3V: Output regulated voltage.

GND: Ground.

AREF: Analog Reference voltage.

Communication Options:

Serial (UART)

I2C (A4-SDA. A5 SCL)

SPI (Pins 10 SS. 11 MOSI. 12 - MISO. 13-SCK)

GND: Ground.

AREF: Analog Reference voltage.

Programming the Board:

Use Arduino IDE (available for Windows. macOS. Linux).

Select Board: Arduino Uno and correct COM port.

Upload code via USB using standard A-B USB cable.

 Common Uses:

LED & buzzer control

Sensor interfacing

Robotics

Home automation

IoT (with WiFi modules)

Educational electronics

Advantages:

Easy to use and program

Extensive documentation and community support

Open-source hardware

Compatible with many shields

ğŸ¯ API into Salesforce to forecast hiring needs based on live sales pipelines
ğŸ¯ Link to HRIS to recommend hiring pipelines based on PiPs, promotions, and performance

ğŸ¯ Model budget impact and scenario planning.  If sales exceed target by X, what's the impact on CS?
ğŸ¯ Suggest regional or skills-based hiring strategies to match talent availability and costs.  We are hiring 10 AI Engineers in SF. Here's the cost forecast based on engineer availability by city and country.
ğŸ¯Integrate with your interview intelligence platform and/or ATS to keep salary info live.
ğŸ¯Then produce a live cost forecast and updates based on predicted salary data, not old salary data.
ğŸ¯Integrate with your ATS for live update start dates and costs.
ğŸ¯ Track and recommend based on changes.  For instance, with 15 engineers added based on existing structures, you will need a Team Lead, a Product Manager, etc.

Anything else AI could do for us?  Is anyone doing this already?

content:
This response was so insightful that I am making a post out of it.

It was a response to this article (which went viral), "They Know a Collapse is Coming": https://lnkd.in/eRp9Vgzc

Here was the response of Rania S. (https://lnkd.in/eQHD3-g4)

Her Response: 

The pace of technological accelerationâ€”especially in AIâ€”is undeniably outstripping both public understanding and policy response. And yes, thereâ€™s clear evidence that elites are preparing for systemic instability, from private bunkers to offshore escapes.

But I want to offer a respectful challenge:
The assumption that AI will replace â€œeverythingâ€ misses something essential. It treats work as a collection of tasksâ€”discrete, automatable actionsâ€”rather than as a space where humans generate meaning, trust, judgment, and belonging. Yes, AI can write code, summarize texts, and even pass the bar.

Whatâ€™s being replaced isnâ€™t peopleâ€”itâ€™s routine. And thatâ€™s a critical distinction. We are in a disruptive moment, no doubtâ€”but thatâ€™s not the same as a terminal one.

History gives us models of transformation that arenâ€™t collapse. The Industrial Revolution was brutalâ€”but it also catalyzed labor movements, public education, and the modern university. The digital revolution upended entire industriesâ€”but it also birthed entirely new ones. AI will do the same. The question is whether we let systems evolve by defaultâ€”or design them with dignity in mind.

Hereâ€™s the deeper reality: when automation displaces human labor, the value doesnâ€™t vanishâ€”it moves. Historically, when machines replaced physical effort, that value shifted from muscle to management, from doing to directing. AI is repeating that pattern. Now, value is moving toward sensemaking, trust-building, and ethical guidanceâ€”skills that may seem â€œsoftâ€ until you realize they are central to leadership, innovation, and stable institutions.

There is money in building trust. In high-stakes systemsâ€”healthcare, law, education, governanceâ€”the human layer of accountability and interpretation is not a luxury. Itâ€™s the insurance policy. Thatâ€™s where payment persists. Thatâ€™s what people will still get hired forâ€”and increasingly, what theyâ€™ll pay extra for.

This isnâ€™t a call for optimism. Itâ€™s a call for grounded authorship. Collapse is only inevitable if we abandon the work of shaping whatâ€™s next.

So far, the only people preparing for the future are either building bunkersâ€”or building AI. We need a third group: those building new systems for human participation in a world where the old structures no longer hold.

content:
Quick rant on â€œauto-remediationâ€ in security tools.

Every AppSec product loves to show off how it can auto-generate PRs to fix vulnerabilities. But letâ€™s be honest, most developers donâ€™t trust code thatâ€™s been auto-generated by a security tool. And unless youâ€™ve got rock-solid test coverage (which most dev teams donâ€™t), thereâ€™s no way that code gets merged without someone taking a closer look.

So what happens?
Thousands of auto-fixesâ€¦ sit. Unmerged. Unreviewed. Forgotten. Zombie PRs everywhere.

Dependabot and Renovate were auto-updating dependencies years ago, long before AI code gen showed up. Did that solve the dependency vuln problem? Nope. Why? Because no one knows what those â€œfixesâ€ will break.

Even worse â€” many of those PRs are fixing issues that donâ€™t even matter to the app.

We donâ€™t need more automation. We need smarter automation â€” the kind that understands whatâ€™s actually exploitable and worth fixing. Otherwise, itâ€™s just noise.

content:
The Best BI Tools for Banks

Despite the hype, its doubtful if #genAI will replace a good dashboard any time soon - it is too hard to quickly visualize your business intelligence (#BI) data compared to a well laid out dashboard. 

Below, are our favorite BI tools ranked that are suitable for a regulated enterprise:

1. PowerBI - Its stable, capable, integrated and near-free for M365 banks. In addition, #Copilot gives the tool new power. The downside is the UX as it has the vibe that it was designed by a committee. 

2.  Tableau - Too artistic for its own good, a steep learning curve and laughably pricy, this BI tool is as powerful and beautiful in its execution. A solid large enterprise choice, but beware - its run by Salesforce which comes with its own sales and future price baggage. 

3. Looker - If you are a Google Cloud bank, then this an obvious choice due to its integration. While clean and scalable, its difficult to learn and use across mobile and desktop. 

4. Qlik Sense / GoodData (Tie) - Both scalable, capable and value-priced. Both have dated UX but both are good to embed in banking products. 

6. Sisense - If your banks goal is to embed BI into various internal and external applications, this tool provides a good backend. The UX is a little difficult for business users. 

7. Omni - This start up should be a consideration for small, tech-forward banks. It has great governance and flexibility that is still being built out but is on the right track with its low data latency and clean modeling layer. If you like Looker, this should be considered for a replacement. 

8. ThoughtSpot - This tool excels in natural language queries and low data latency. The Company just acquired Mode which was go-to for SQL-lovers and fawned over for its tight integration with Python & R. This BI tool is better for limited data graphics and not great for full product dashboards. 

Your thoughts? 

#data #dataanalytics #datavisualization #banking

ğŸš€ Why SQL is the Heart of Data Analytics! ğŸ’¡

In the world of Data Analytics, if there's one language every analyst MUST know, it's SQL (Structured Query Language).

But why SQL? ğŸ¤”
ğŸ‘‰ Because data lives in databases, and SQL is the bridge between raw data and valuable insights.

ğŸ” What SQL Can Do (That Others Often Canâ€™t):

Retrieve exactly the data you need from millions of rows ğŸ“Š

Perform powerful joins to connect multiple tables ğŸ”—

Filter, group, sort, and aggregate data lightning-fast âš¡

Build logic using subqueries, CTEs, and window functions ğŸ§ 

It's universal â€” works with MySQL, PostgreSQL, MS SQL Server, Oracle & more ğŸŒ

SQL is simple yet powerful, making it a non-negotiable skill for Data Analysts, Data Scientists & Business Intelligence professionals.

ğŸ¯ Most Common SQL Interview Topics for Analytics Roles:

ğŸ‘¶ Beginner Level:

SELECT, WHERE, GROUP BY, ORDER BY

COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN

JOINS (INNER, LEFT, RIGHT, FULL)

DISTINCT, ALIAS, BETWEEN, IN, LIKE

Basic Subqueries

ğŸš€ Advanced Level:

WINDOW FUNCTIONS (ROW_NUMBER, RANK, DENSE_RANK)

CTEs (Common Table Expressions)

CASE WHEN Statements

Correlated Subqueries

Data Cleaning with SQL

Performance Tuning & Indexing

Real-world Scenario-based Querying
