content:
Are you a founder, developer, or designer building AI agent for analytics ?
Your UI is already outdated. 

If you're building an AI product for analytics or business intelligence, this blog is for you.

Traditional analytics interfaces like dashboards were built for the pre-AI era. They worked when users had predictable, limited questions.
AI changed everything. Now users can dive into data as easily as having a conversation â€“ asking anything, anytime.

But here are 3 problems you'll face:
âœ¦ Users can ask infinite questions. Your traditional dashboard won't be able to handle infinite use cases.
âœ¦ LLMs return Text responses, which are terrible for consuming data insights and kill user engagement.
âœ¦ You can build templates, but scaling and maintaining dozens of chart variations will crush your team.

The solution = Generative UI 
Instead of pre-building interfaces, let AI generate them in real-time. Each user question creates a custom interface â†’ the right chart, best layout, and relevant interactions for that specific insight.

Your AI can analyze anything. Shouldn't your UI be able to display it?
Here's a detailed blog (link in comments).

#AI #Analytics #ProductDevelopment

AI is changing how we work and whoâ€™s accountable when things go wrong. From boardrooms to trading desks, machine-driven decisions now carry 
weight once reserved for human judgment. But with this transformation comes a critical question:

Can fiduciary duty survive automation?

As algorithms guide portfolios, advise clients, and influence high-stakes decisions, the traditional safeguards of trust, diligence, and oversight are under pressure. Robo-advisors donâ€™t panic but they also donâ€™t take responsibility. And when AI fails, it wonâ€™t be the system thatâ€™s held liable, itâ€™ll be the board, the advisor, the fiduciary who signed off.

With regulators closing in, compliance expectations rising, and litigation risks mounting, AI is a tech investment and a governance stress test.

Think of it as the convergence of innovation and obligation. And for those in positions of trust, the future is intelligent and accountable.

content:
Rethinking Compliance: From Obligation to Opportunity

Compliance used to feel like a tedious checkbox exercise. But as Gartner points out, it's now evolving into a genuine competitive advantage.

It's also worth highlighting that ASC Technologies has been named as a key player driving this shift.

Compliance shouldnâ€™t just be a requirement; it should be a strategic advantage.

content:
Over the past month, My team and Iâ€™ve been auditing smart infrastructure deployments across the Middle East - grid modernization, urban IoT, BMS rollouts.

At first glance:
1. Impressive systems. 
2. Adaptive. Automated. Optimized.

But beneath the orchestration layers - 
1. A familiar fragility.
2. Protocol-layer exposure. 
3. Flat segmentation. 
4. Zero telemetry at the control plane.

Many of these â€œsmartâ€ environments still rely on:
1. BACnet, Modbus, DNP3 unauthenticated, unencrypted. 
2. Legacy HMIs secured by shared credentials. 
3. Always-on vendor VPNs with no audit logging. 
4. Flat Layer 2 networks with no real segmentation enforcement. 

Weâ€™ve architected intelligent systems on blind, trust-based protocols. In late 2024, a UAE utility saw the danger before it became a headline. 

They overhauled their smart grid security posture:
1. Protocol-aware IDS (Claroty, Nozomi)
2. Vendor tiering by blast radius
3. Real-time OTâ€“SIEM correlation
4. Enforced firewall policy at control zones
5. They moved from compliance â†’ control.

The real risk isnâ€™t malware. Itâ€™s architectural complacency. We assume segmentation is enforced.
That dashboards equal visibility.
That SLAs = resilience. But attackers donâ€™t exploit technology. They exploit belief systems.

What the top 1% of critical infrastructure operators now measure:
1. Trust boundaries, not VLANs
2. Telemetry by behavior, not status
3. Vendor access tied to runtime context
4. IR plans integrated with plant ops, not siloed in IT

DM me if your grid or automation layer assumes trust by design.

I'll share the Zero Trust OT blueprint and breach recovery drill framework we use across GCC energy, water, and transport networks.

Because in cyber-physical systems, survivability > prevention.

#SmartCitySecurity #OTSecurity #CyberResilience #ZeroTrustOT #CriticalInfrastructure #CISO #Microminder

content:
Chennai-based robotics deeptech startup Unibose Technology Private Limited has raised Rs 5.5 crore in pre-Series A funding to scale its ATEX Zone-0 compliant robotic solutions for hazardous and confined industrial environments. The round was led by o2 Angels Network, with participation from IN44 Capital, COIMBATORE INNOVATION AND BUSINESS INCUBATOR, and other strategic angels.

Founded by Manikandan Dakshinamoorthy, Samayaraj D, Sakthivel Panneerselvam, and Venkatesh Sundaramurthy, Unibose operates on a Robotics-as-a-Service (RaaS) model, making life-saving automation accessible to industries like oil & gas, chemicals, fertilizers, and heavy engineering â€” sectors where safety risks and compliance challenges are high. Its flagship NMER robot is capable of operating in zero-oxygen, toxic, and explosive zones that have traditionally been off-limits to humans.

The capital will be used to scale operations across India, GCC, and Southeast Asia, deepen R&D in AI-led inspection tools, and build a robust OEM and partner ecosystem.

content:
Over 80% of AI projects fail. And itâ€™s not because of the technology.
Itâ€™s leadership.
Itâ€™s strategy.
Itâ€™s infrastructure.
Itâ€™s people.

The latest AI Strategy Playbook 2025 Edition from Devoteam reveals hard truths about the gap between AI hype and AI impact. If your AI strategy isnâ€™t business-led, people-first, and rooted in strong foundations, your â€œtransformationâ€ is likely headed nowhere.

Top Lessons from the Playbook:
âœ… Strategy First, Not Tech First:
Avoid the â€œready, fire, aimâ€ trap. Start with the business problem, not the AI solution.
âœ… ROI Is Real, If You Measure It:
Expect ~3.7x return per dollar invested in GenAI. But only when aligned to productivity, financial, operational, and strategic goals.
âœ… Infrastructure Matters:
Cloud, data governance, and cybersecurity are non-negotiable. AI security still lags behindâ€”fix that.
âœ… People Over Platforms:
Fear, skill gaps, and mindset will make or break adoption. Upskilling is not optional. Itâ€™s survival.
âœ… Ethics Canâ€™t Be an Afterthought:
Transparency, bias mitigation, accountability, and sustainability require governance not wishful thinking.

Your AI projects donâ€™t fail because AI doesnâ€™t work. They fail because businesses skip the hard parts: strategy, people, foundations.

If you want AI to deliver, treat it as organizational transformationâ€”not IT automation.

Credit to the report's authors:
Olivier Mallet, Jacob Axelsen, and the Devoteam AI Agency Team.

content:
The skills-based organisation:
The professional landscape is rapidly evolving, driven by factors like labor shortages and changing skill availability, posing challenges for organizations to innovate and expand. Automation and digital transformation are reshaping roles, creating a demand for new job profiles. 

Workplace agility, creativity, and innovation are gaining prominence, prompting leaders to explore novel work approaches. The current climate of talent wars and the Great Resignation is fostering a restive workforce open to significant changes!

What is a skills based organisation? 
A skills-based organization prioritizes skills and capabilities in recruitment and talent management, alongside traditional roles. This approach focuses on hiring based on project-specific skills rather than job titles or qualifications, enhancing adaptability and innovation.

Adopting skills-based workforce planning allows organisations to proactively identify, develop, and leverage critical skills for success. By aligning skills with business needs, organisations can ensure they have the right expertise at the right time, setting the stage for both short-term wins and sustained growth.

content:
Relieved. Grateful. Slightly exhausted. 

Just wrapped up the final step of the United States Artificial Intelligence Institute â€“ Certified Artificial Intelligence Consultant certification by passing the exam! Iâ€™ve taken my fair share of certification tests, and usually, I walk out knowing whether I cleared it or if I need to start burning the midnight oil. But this one? Total wildcard. 

Some reflections from the journey:
1. Steady foundation for IT professionals â€“ It's not just about AI/ML buzzwords or toolkits. This program dives deep into how these technologies align with business strategyâ€”great for both techies and business folks.

2. Time investment is real â€“ Two thick textbooks, a mountain of collateral material, and about 6 months of commitment. Thankful for USAII's updated portal that kept things fresh.

3. Workplace-ready knowledge â€“ Whether youâ€™re into risk, architecture, or somewhere in between, thereâ€™s a ton you can take back to your day job and put into action.

4. Advanced stats & code? Buckle up. Some of the more technical chapters had me revisiting them multiple times. Definitely not a one-and-done.

5. AI/ML is a moving target â€“ This isnâ€™t the kind of program where you â€œfinishâ€ and close the book. Itâ€™s a launchpad. The learning continuesâ€”and so will mine.

A big thank you to my manager, Art Chaisiriwatanasai, for supporting this endeavor. It means a lot to work with people who invest in your growth.
Upward and onward!

content:
In 2024, I had the privilege of attending a security conference. As a first-timer, I was given a slot to present during the graveyard shiftâ€”a time slot where keeping the audience engaged is notoriously challenging.

I realized quickly that if I wanted to make an impact, I couldnâ€™t deliver a typical, feature-dense sales pitch. Instead, I decided to present a â€œLess is Moreâ€ concept in security deploymentâ€”a shift away from over-engineering systems for the sake of ticking boxes, toward intelligent, strategic deployment that prioritizes outcomes over hardware volume.

We live in a world of camera overload. The default reaction to security concerns is often: Install more cameras. But does that really solve the problem?
Of course, surveillance is critical in security, but are we truly being strategic about how we deploy it? Or are we just recording evidence after the fact, instead of preventing or predicting incidents?

Rather than just piling on more devices, use smarter technology, driven by AI and real-time data. Cameras shouldnâ€™t just see; they should analyze, decide, and alertâ€”at the edge, without human intervention until necessary.
Security systems should do more than record; they should inform and predict. The real value is not in watching endless footage, but in being alerted to meaningful events before loss occurs.
Would you rather know that a convicted shoplifter is entering your store now? Or review 3 hours of footage tomorrow to find out youâ€™ve been hit again?
Security no longer operates in isolation. With modern AI-driven systems, security becomes part of business intelligence. Understand behaviour, track anomalies and Combine databases to identify potential threats.
Less hardware. More intelligence.

#smartsecurity #lpr #facecam #visitormanagement

II disappeared from LinkedIn 6 months ago. Here's why I'm back.

Over a year ago, I was running a successful Klaviyo email marketing agency from Paris. Good clients, growing team, everything looked perfect from the outside.

But I was burned out. The quality was slipping. I was managing people instead of doing the work I loved. And honestly? The email marketing space felt like everyone was saying the same things over and over.

So I made a radical decision:

â€¢ Let go of most of my team
â€¢ Scaled back to a small practice
â€¢ Moved to a small beach town in Southern Italy
â€¢ Took time to actually think

What I discovered changed everything.

While everyone was recycling the same email marketing advice, two massive shifts happened:

1ï¸âƒ£ Klaviyo launched Advanced Marketing Analytics (most agencies still don't know it exists)

2ï¸âƒ£ AI tools like Claude became sophisticated enough to build actual business intelligence systems

I've spent the last 6 months mastering both.

Now I'm back with a completely different approach to email marketing. Less campaigns, more customer intelligence. Less guesswork, more AI-powered insights.

Over the next few weeks, I'll be sharing exactly what I learned and how it's changing everything for my clients.

Fair warning: This isn't your typical "5 subject line tips" content.

content:
Hereâ€™s what you already know: AI is revolutionizing how communicators and marketers approach their day-to-day work, and if you're not learning to maximize it, you're falling behind. 

Now, here's how I used AI to automate my real-world busy work, freeing up time for big ideas: Each month, I spent 3-4 hours extracting data from image-based PDFs and formatting it into spreadsheets. I knew there had to be a better way using AI.

First, I used Anthropic and their product Claude to build a prompt that could extract the PDF data. That was the easy part. But I hit a wall: Claude couldn't produce spreadsheets directly, so I could only automate so much.

While this drastically reduced my time, I knew it could be better. That's when I turned to Zapier, a platform for workflow automation. 

I created a 10-step workflow triggered by simply adding a file to a Google Drive folder. Five minutes after uploading the original PDF, I have a formatted Google Sheet ready to go. One copy-paste into my Excel template, and I'm done.

The result? A task that took several hours now takes under 10 minutes.

The best part: I did this with zero coding experience, zero Zapier experience, and minimal understanding of workflow automation. That's the beauty of AIâ€”anyone with a computer and the drive to learn can create processes that lighten their workload and make time for what really matters.

content:
I finally carved out some time to play around with MCP (Model Context Protocol) and my mind is blown.

Today I installed two MCP servers that interact with
- Chrome
- my download folder on my computer (it could access the whole file system but for now, I prefer it in a small box)

I tend to have a lot of browser tabs open and sometimes end up with duplicates. I asked Claude to identify any dupes and then requested it close them.

That was an easy request.

Next, I asked Claude if there were things it could do to organize my Downloads folder.
It identified the following categories:
- Art & creative content
-Financial documents 
-Software installers 
- Photos and screenshots 
- Media files

I asked if it could take all of the installers and put them into a new folder.
This was another trivial request, (though it took a bit more time than I'd have expected and it was somewhat noisy in telling me what i was doing. But I'd assume a prompt could reduce all the chatter.)

Meanwhile, I've been developing my expertise in automation tools like Zapier and Make but now find myself wondering if their lifespan is limited. 

I believe there's still a lot that MCP can't do without R&D skills. But I imagine there's going to be a gold rush of new extensions that can interact with all of our everyday tools.

I'm blown away by what I've been able to do with this today. 

Have you done anything with MCP yet?

What do you think?

#Productivity #MCP #Automation #TechTrends #Claude #AgenticAI

article.title: 10 Steps to Unlocking a Winners Mindset
article.subtitle: Kaysi Coelho-Curtin
article.linkLabel: Open article: 10 Steps to Unlocking a Winners Mindset by Kaysi Coelho-Curtin â€¢ 4 min read

content:
"We tend to overestimate the effect of a technology in the short run and underestimate the effect in the long run."
  - Roy Amara

If I could describe the current state of AI with one quote - this is it!!!

ğŸ” In Simple Terms:

Short-term hype: When a new technology emerges people often expect too much too soon

Long-term impact: Over time, as the tech matures and integrates into society, its true transformational power becomes more profound than originally imagined

ğŸ˜µâ€ğŸ’« I lived through this in 1994 - 2000 when I was evangelizing B2B eCommerce - here are some lessons learned which may be valuable for anyone trying to predict the impact of AI to their company career and life...

1ï¸âƒ£ Your job is NOT SAFE unless you learn how to embrace the technology that is shaping the future

- don't be that Sales professional who says AI will NEVER replace me
- Agentic AI may not replace you TODAY - but sales professionals who know how to leverage and use the power of AI will replace those who don't

2ï¸âƒ£ Your company is NOT SAFE unless you embrace how AI can either change the value of your software product AND increase the productivity of your operations

- the number of use cases and tangible ROI is not yet at the level that we could say AI applied to operations is mature - but the LESSONS being learned now through experimentation and failed projects are the foundation for future success

- Microsoft has reduced (laid off) 15,000 people in the last 2 months (~ 7% of workforce
- Mircosoft reported ~ $500M in savings due to AI and Automation
- At the same time they announced ~$80B AI infrastructure build out

Story: 

My division of GE was the largest provider of B2B eCommerce via a legacy technology called EDI and time-sharing back in 1994.

They even did a joint venture with Netscape which brought me to Silicon Valley - the goal was to "LEARN" about the internet and internet B2B Commerce but ultimately they were too concerned with protecting their legacy revenue streams and ended being bought by PE at a significant discount because they had lost the opportunity to lead the next generation of B2B ecommerce and hosted applications (SaaS)

ğŸ’¡ Invest in the future being created by AI - it's not a question of "IF AI will change society, business and your life?"...

ğŸ¦‰ ...it is a question of HOW you will embrace AI to change your business, your career and your life

"FAILURE is the Road to Success" is a quote often associated with Thomas Edison - the founder of GE

"Change before you have to" is a quote from Jack Welch, former CEO of GE who was my role model for many years while I was at GE Information Services

The above is a key reason why we are doing several original research projects on how AI is being adopted and impacting productivity across departments

IF YOU HAVE a story about deploying AI in your business and the ROI achieved - DM me to be a guest on my new podcast "AI to ROI"

That was my breaking point.

So I spent the next 60 days documenting every process.

Sales, onboarding, content, reporting, paymentsâ€”everything.
â†’ I built templates for client comms.

â†’ Trained my team to run the business without me.

And hereâ€™s what happened:
Revenue grew 40%.

I finally took a vacationâ€”with zero messages from the team.

This isnâ€™t just a productivity hack.
Itâ€™s survival.

McKinsey found that companies with strong systems and processes areÂ 2.7x more likelyÂ to be top performers.

Until you document, delegate, and automateâ€”

content:
Not going to lie, 12th Fail gave me goosebumps.
I probably teared up ten times.

Thereâ€™s no big, dramatic rock-bottom moment in the film.
Because the protagonist, IPS Manoj Sharma didnâ€™t fail once, he failed repeatedly.

In exams. In interviews. In life.
And each time, instead of giving up, he makes the harder choice: 

He restarts.

That word, restart, hit home for me.

Well, to be honest, Evallo - Tutoring Business Automation isnâ€™t my first company.

Itâ€™s my third officially, but really, it's my fifth.

Some never took off. Others collapsed midway.

Even within Evallo, there have been points where I didnâ€™t think weâ€™d make it.

Iâ€™ve lost my savings trying to keep it alive. Iâ€™ve fought my way back up, only to hit another wall. Something breaks, I fix it. Then something else goes wrong. I lose someone important, or something unexpected throws the whole plan off course.

It wouldâ€™ve been easy to stop. Honestly, some days it still would be.

But Iâ€™ve learned that you donâ€™t fail when things fall apart. You fail the day you decide to stop rebuilding.
Startups arenâ€™t about clean upward curves. Theyâ€™re messy, unpredictable loops. You fall. You restart. You fall again. And what really carries you through isnâ€™t brilliance or luck, itâ€™s consistency and stubbornness. Itâ€™s the decision to show up when no oneâ€™s clapping.

This movie reminded me of those moments. Not the big wins, but the nights you sit with the mess and still choose to move.

#founderdiaries #12thfail #persistence

content:
"Hi {first_name}, hope you're well!"
You donâ€™t.
Weâ€™ve never met.
Youâ€™re an email template with commitment issues.
Every day, my inbox is a costume party of fake familiarity:
--> A stranger who "loved my recent podcast" (I don't have one)
--> Someone "just following up again" (they never followed up the first time)
--> A bold offer... addressed to "Omer Maman Maman"

We've mistaken automation for affection. And it shows.

Here's my unpopular opinion:
Using my name isn't personalization.
Knowing my context is.

If you want to stand out, try this:
--> Mention something specific I actually did (download, event, comment)
--> Sound like a human, not a compliance bot
--> Skip the fake small talk. Be useful. Be fast. Be a little weird.

I don't need "Hi Omer"
I need "Saw your Healthee walkthrough. Want feedback?"

Marketing magic doesn't live in merge tags.
It lives in context, curiosity, and the courage to skip the fluff.


What's the worst "personalized" message you've ever received?
(Iâ€™m collecting them for a future comedy tour. Seriously!)

content:
I used to see my career as a series of BIG steps: the big job promotion, the most senior title, the high-profile project.

Maybe through failure, or through perspective, I've learned that small steps are more rewarding the big ones.

For me, this means:
- A short YouTube video, not a Certificate.
- A 1-hour course, not a Masterâ€™s Degree.
- A blog post or newsletter, not a textbook.

Over the last year that's amounted to thousands of hours of content - all about AI, LLMs, agents, automations...

I've put in the long hours, but in small steps. 

This means that I've been able to pivot and follow my curiosity. 

I've been able to build just what I need (and what I think all other business leaders need).

PS. This is me outside. Screw the air conditioning. Heat gives me energy. Am I weird?

content:
1. Intelligent Systems Are Becoming Standard
Water infrastructure is getting smarter. Utilities are integrating real-time monitoring and automation into their networks. Intelligent systems enable faster response times, reduce water loss, and lower operational strain.
They represent the new baseline in field-ready intelligence. When paired with cloud-based platforms, they empower utilities to act proactively and sustainably.

2. Connectivity Is Crucial
Secure, reliable connectivity is foundational to any modern water system.
Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) and Automated Meter Reading (AMR) rely on durable, watertight physical connections to deliver consistent, accurate data. Kamstrup water meters â€” deployed in millions of installations worldwide â€” ensure performance and reliability even in the harshest field conditions.

3. Predictive Maintenance Is Gaining Momentum
Gone are the days of waiting for systems to fail. Today, predictive analytics is helping utilities anticipate problems before they cause disruption.
Kamstrup water meters support municipalities, homeowners, and commercial properties by revealing leaks and inefficiencies in real time. The result: longer asset life, reduced maintenance costs, and improved service reliability.

4. Real-Time Data Supports Sustainability
In a world facing increasing water scarcity, visibility is key. Real-time data helps utilities and end users optimize consumption, detect anomalies, and ensure responsible water use.
Technologies built for precision â€” such as low-flow detection and continuous leak monitoring, both features of Kamstrup meters â€” enable communities to manage water with transparency and purpose.

A Global Trendâ€¦
Governments, utilities, and private partners are investing in smart water technologies at an unprecedented scale. But challenges persist â€” especially aging infrastructure and budget constraints.
Kamstrup water meters are designed to help overcome these barriers. They are cost-effective, future-ready, and built to last.

The Future Is Now
2025 marks a turning point. Smart water systems arenâ€™t just upgrades, theyâ€™re strategic investments in community resilience, operational efficiency, and long-term sustainability.

content:
Just wrapped up the Generative AI Foundations Certificate program by upGrad.

It was a useful deep dive; not into buzzwords, but into the actual mechanics of how generative AI works and how it's already changing the way we work, create, and communicate. From understanding how large language models like GPT are built, to experimenting with prompt design, the program helped me make sense of the tech thatâ€™s increasingly becoming part of everyday workflows.
Here are a few takeaways Iâ€™m walking away with:
1. The difference between traditional AI vs generative AI, and why the latter is a game-changer
2. HowÂ foundation modelsÂ like GPT and DALLÂ·E are trained and fine-tuned
3. Real-world applications across content creation, marketing, design, education, and customer experience
4. The power (and limits) ofÂ prompt engineeringÂ in getting the right output
5. Most importantly, the importance ofÂ human oversight, ethical use, and responsible AI adoption in todayâ€™s evolving landscape

What stood out the most? That AI, when used thoughtfully, can complement human thinking (not compete with it). Thatâ€™s where I see real potential.

Iâ€™m looking forward to applying some of these insights in my work, and continuing to explore where human creativity and machine intelligence can meet in the middle.

If you're exploring how to use AI more meaningfully in your field, happy to exchange notes.

content:
AI is not the future.
It's the now.
And if you're not adapting, you're falling behind.
â†’ In marketing, AI writes faster than your whole team
 â†’ In finance, it forecasts and flags anomalies in seconds
 â†’ In HR, it screens thousands of resumes in one click
 â†’ In software, it ships features before lunch
I work with founders and execs every week.
They're not asking if they should use AI.
They're asking how fast they can rebuild their org around it.
We used to hire for productivity.
 Now we're hiring for adaptability.
The people winning right now understand three things:
â†’ AI is not magicâ€”it's a tool
 â†’ The tool is only as useful as the operator
 â†’ If you can't prompt it, you can't lead it
So here's the real skill gap:
Not coding.
Not data science.
AI literacy.
Can you:
 â†’ Use LLMs to ideate, write, edit, analyze, and summarize?
 â†’ Audit AI outputs for bias and accuracy?
 â†’ Integrate AI into your daily workflows?
That's the new bar.
I've met CMOs who can prompt better than their content team.
 I've met engineers who built internal tools using GPT-4 without writing a line of code.
The question isn't â€œWill AI take my job?â€
The question is:
 Will someone using AI take it instead?

content:
Here's a snapshot of AI adoption: 

The global AI industry has reached a market size of $244 billion - that's a 31% increase over the past year, and it's projected to hit $1 trillion by 2031. 

AI is officially mainstream, with 66% of people using it regularly. And the number of AI tool users is expected to reach 378 million in 2025, a dramatic jump from 116 million five years ago.

Organizations are rapidly integrating AI, with 78% of businesses report using AI, up from 55% the previous year. In healthcare, 90% of hospitals now use AI for diagnosis and monitoring. Education has seen a surge, with 92% of students using generative AI (up from 66% in 2024), and 18% admitting to submitting AI-generated work. (These are a couple of the challenges - educators are working on it!) 

More than 50% of marketers already use generative AI, and another 22% plan to adopt it soon. 

These trends highlight the accelerating global reliance on AI across industries and demographics. Thanks to Bernard Marr for these "numbers that tell a story" and other remarkable stats in his recent LinkedIn newsletter! https://lnkd.in/gWbXrfq6

#AIAdoption #AITrends #ArtificialIntelligence #FutureOfAI #AIImpact #AIinBusiness #leadership #globalmobility #onboarding #talentacquisition

content:
Start with the work.

If we donâ€™t understand how itâ€™s actually getting done, AI wonâ€™t help us do it better.
In my last post, I shared why mapping real work across the customer experience is a critical first step before layering in AI. This post digs into how to do that in practice and why the level of detail matters.

In many companies serving business customers, work happens across fragmented systems, tribal knowledge, and unwritten playbooks. Over time, responsibilities shift, gaps emerge, and the real way work gets done drifts from whatâ€™s on paper.

This is especially true in customer experience functions like Implementation, Customer Success, and Support.

Thatâ€™s why task mapping is such a useful starting point. Itâ€™s not about creating detailed SOPs. Itâ€™s about asking:
â€¢ What work is actually being done?
â€¢ Whoâ€™s doing it, and who thinks they are?
â€¢ What does â€œdone wellâ€ look like?
â€¢ Where are the handoffs, duplications, or delays?

You donâ€™t need to map everything. Focus on tasks that are easy to compartmentalize and connect to a clear outcomeâ€”something measurable, or something that unlocks the next step.

Think: prepare onboarding checklist, summarize meeting notes, follow up on implementation milestone.

The long-term goal is to define work in units that could eventually be reassigned or automated, by either a person or an AI agent. That is what makes way for the remix we will talk more about soon.

AI can help here too.
LLMs are surprisingly effective at turning transcripts, meeting notes, and scattered docs into draft workflows, FAQs, or role definitions. You can even prompt them to flag gaps based on best practices.

Itâ€™s not a magic bullet, but itâ€™s a fast way to turn informal knowledge into something visible and searchable. That creates alignment and sets the stage for real transformation.

When you put the work on the table, two things happen:
You see where friction is holding teams back
You start to spot where AI can reduce effort or enhance judgment

It also helps when evaluating vendors. Without this clarity, itâ€™s easy to chase features that donâ€™t match the real work or add complexity.

You donâ€™t need perfect documentation to get started.
You need visibility, shared understanding, and just enough structure to design what comes next.

Iâ€™ve seen how even simple role mapping and RACI-style frameworks can surface misalignments that stall both people and platforms. We will get into that more in the next post.

ğŸ’¬ Have you ever uncovered something unexpected when mapping out a process? What did it change for your team?

#CustomerExperience #AIinBusiness #WorkflowDesign #ProcessImprovement #TaskMapping #AgenticAI #SaaS

content:
6 Easy steps to build the right cybersecurity program for you.

Cybersecurity programs don't have to be overly complicated or expensive. 

These are simple & critical steps you can take to build a great program, no matter what your size or budget

Here's the process â¬‡ï¸

1. Start with Strategy
â†’ Ensure you are aligned with the business
â†’ Decide how you will make decisions about the program
â†’ Decide how much risk you are willing to take & where (risk appetite)
â†’ Identify what you must comply with (consider your risk appetite) 

2. Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
â†’ Identify ALL assets
â†’ Assets are not just hardware, but apps, data, & processes
â†’ Define criticality, most important to least, this will help determine how much you need to protect them 

3. Risk Assessment
â†’ Evaluate the risks to the business, use intelligence, threat modeling, and testing to further validate
â†’ Determine how likely the risk is and the potential impact
â†’ Prioritize risks based on steps 1 & 2

4. Gap Assessment
â†’ Choose a framework (ie NIST CSF, ISO27k)
â†’ Add your compliance requirements
â†’ Assess the business against it all, determine where you are (current state)
â†’ Define a desired end state

5. Road Map
â†’ Current state to desired state defines gaps
â†’ Gabs require projects or tasks, map these out
â†’ Prioritize these gaps, build out short & long term road maps

6. Budget & Execute
â†’ Get estimates to bridge all gaps
â†’ Budget, prioritize based on criticality, risk and cost
â†’ Start executing gap projects

ğŸ§™ğŸ¼â€â™‚ï¸ It's pretty simple... at the end of the day you want to make sure security is spent protecting the areas most important to the business. 

Don't assume you need anything without having assessed those needs vs business mission. 

What step do you think is most often missed? â¬‡ï¸

ğŸ”„ Repost to help others protect their business

content:
Demystified Data Day 9: Data Warehouse

ğŸ¢ Demystifying Data - One Term at a Time

The traditional stronghold of analytical data: The Data Warehouseâ€”still going strong after all these years.

What it actually is: A central repository where data from various sources comes together, gets cleaned up, organized, and stored in a way that makes analysis a breeze. Think of it as your organization's "single source of truth" for historical data.

Why it's not dead (despite what vendors say): Data warehouses excel at:
âœ… Consistent, reliable reporting
âœ… Complex business intelligence queries
âœ… Historical trend analysis
âœ… Regulatory compliance reporting

For structured, well-understood business data, they're still king.

Here's why YOU should care: That executive dashboard you check every morning? Those quarterly reports the board reviews? Your ability to answer "How did we perform last year?" All powered by the humble data warehouse.

The evolution story: Modern cloud warehouses (Snowflake, BigQuery, Redshift) have solved the old problems of scale and cost. You can now query billions of rows in seconds without buying a server farm.

Common pitfall: Trying to shove everything into your warehouse. Real-time streaming data? Unstructured content? That's like using a Swiss Army knife as a hammerâ€”wrong tool for the job.

Learn more:
-- Book: "The Data Warehouse Toolkit" by Ralph Kimball
-- Newsletter: The Analytics Engineering Weekly
-- Follow: Bob Muglia (@bobmuglia) - Former Snowflake CEO
-- Connected topics: Dimensional modeling, Star schemas, Kimball vs. Inmon

Is your data warehouse a source of truth or a source of frustration? What would you change? ğŸ’­

#DataWarehouse #BusinessIntelligence #Snowflake #DemystifyingData #Analytics

From Day 1 at Amazon to Mentoring the Next Generation in Data Science

In November 2018, I received this emailâ€”
My first official welcome to Amazon India.
It marked the beginning of a journey Iâ€™ll never forget.

That experience taught me the value of technical depth, adaptability, and continuous learning.

Today, after years in the data science field, Iâ€™ve shifted focus:
From solving business problems to helping others launch their careers.

Hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned along the way:
Whether youâ€™re a fresher or a professional looking to transition, technical skills always take priority.

For Data Analysts:
â€¢ SQL and database management
â€¢ Data visualization (Power BI, Tableau)

â€¢ Business intelligence and reporting

For Data Scientists:

â€¢ Statistics and probability

But here's the keyâ€”technical skills are only 50% of the equation.
To stand out, you need:

content:
This week, Camilla Matias and I had the joy of hosting a dinner themed "Agents in the Wild" on how AI agents are actually being deployed inside fast-scaling companiesâ€”beyond the hype, decks, and demos. And fittingly, the stories around the table were just as wild as the tech: a bear stand-off, jumping off a burning Caltrain, buying a government-auction lighthouse.

Between bites and laughs, we surfaced 10 real trends that reflect how AI agents are evolving inside organizations:

ğŸ”’ 1. On-prem is back. 80â€“85% of enterprise deployments are now in VPC. Security, compliance, and the need for tighter control over data pipelines are pushing companies toward self-hosted models. 

ğŸ¤ 2. High-touch enterprise sales are (still) king. AI is bringing back multi-stakeholder, in-person, consultative enterprise sales. Companies are buying trust, not only tools.

ğŸ§© 3. Data orchestration challenge persists. AI agents are only as smart as the data they can see. Integrating siloed SaaS data is still a massive blocker, fueling interest in data ownership, self-hosted solutions, and clean integration layers.

ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» 4. FDEs are a double-edged sword. FDEs have become essential to navigating deployment complexity. But overreliance on FDEs may slow down productization.

ğŸ§¯ 5. Real-time controls matter. As agents gain autonomy, so must their oversight. Enterprises demand real-time observability, rollback options, and mitigation controls. 

ğŸŒ± 6. Land & Expand > boil the ocean. Successful deployments often start with one team, not the whole org. From there, companies expand agent adoption across departments.

ğŸ“ˆ 7. Full autonomy = real ROI. Back-office automation shows clearest returns, especially when tied to measurable outcomes like time saved, leads closed, or ticket resolution.

ğŸ§  8. Multi-agent systems are emerging. Complex workflows call for aggregation agents that manage parallel or sequential actions and cross-vendor agent interoperability.

ğŸ› ï¸ 9. Build AND Buy. Building agents for proprietary workflows, while buying vendor solutions for standardized use cases. Tech-forward companies lean toward the former while traditional industries prefer the latter.

ğŸ“Š 10. Adoption varies by function. Eng and marketing show the highest adoption due to clear ROI. Finance most resistant, largely due to compliance, risks and accuracy. Sales are mixed: great for PLG, trickier for complex enterprise sales cycles.

Hearty thanks to everyone who shared this wonderful evening with us. Andrew Ferguson from Databricks, Cristina Cordova from Linear, Marc Wendling from Glean, Mary M. Liu from Runway, Kent Walters from Retool, JoÃ£o (Joe) Moura from CrewAI, Yash Sheth from Galileo, Yash Patil from Applied Compute, Zack Reneau-Wedeen from Sierra.

If youâ€™re deploying agents inside your org, building for enterprise use, or interested in attending the next dinner, please leave a comment. Always happy to compare notes.

cc F-Prime, David Jegen, Brex, Ambika Kumar, Rachel Feely-Kohl, Lucia DG

content:
Itâ€™s been about three months since we first sat down to figure out what monday magic could be.
It started with a fast-paced sprint with a small team: I got to work with Tsemach Lifshitz and Naor Solomon on the dev side, and Daniel Hai and Danielle Vertman Aviv on product and design. It was one of those rare teams where everyone was all in and super motivated, focused on building a completely new experience for our customers. A different way to discover and start using monday, and maybe even a new kind of acquisition funnel for us.

Over the past few years, I havenâ€™t been very hands-on in the code, as my IC role at monday has become much broader. This was a good chance to dive back into fast, iterative development with lots of complexity and moving parts. monday is a much bigger company than when I joined seven years ago, and this reminded me how fun and chaotic (in a good way) it can be to build something new inside it.

From the start, I told Tsemach and Naor that this was their project. I helped get things going, then stepped back so they could take full ownership. That worked really well! They kept pushing forward, brought in their own initiatives and creativity, and kept the momentum going. Itâ€™s been great to see how theyâ€™ve shaped it.

Just yesterday, on launch day, Tsemach Lifshitz added one of the coolest features so far: an AI-generated onboarding "video" that walks you through the solution monday magic created. The idea was his. He built a quick version, and just put it out there. It really helps explain the final output in a clear and simple way (and it's only the first lean version of it).

Looking ahead, we're exploring how monday magic can work together with monday vibe, our soon to be released vibe coding tool, to create full custom work applications, based entirely on user intent. Vibe provides a new way to design rich UI experiences, while using mondayâ€™s data layer and platform building blocks as the backend. That means the products built with magic wonâ€™t just look good - theyâ€™ll be fully native, with all the flexibility and power of the monday platform underneath.

If you havenâ€™t tried monday magic yet, nowâ€™s a good time. Just describe what you need, and your workflow builds itself. Boards, forms, dashboards - and soon also automations.

Try it at https://mondaymagic.ai!!

content:
After 500+ clients, I've learned something.

Every business comes down to three levers.

Our focus is to move the three levers that make a business go BRRRRR.

Lever 1: List Growth

Most people convert at 2% and take what they can get. But minimum should be 5%, ideally 10%+.

We had a client stuck at 2% for years. Changed their offer strategy around bundles instead of generic discounts. Jumped to 12% overnight.

Lever 2: Automations

The flows are fundamentally the same whether you're selling chapstick or $20K house plans.

People visit, opt-in, browse, cart, buy, then what happens after.

Lever 3: Retention

Getting the first sale is just the beginning.

The real money is in repeat purchases and lifetime value.

We increased one client's repeat purchases by 17% just by fixing their post-purchase sequence.

But here's the thingâ€¦ it's fundamentally always the same across every business type.

The mechanics don't change.

Only the messaging and timing adapt to your specific market.

content:
NOT ALL AGENTIC AI IS DISRUPTIVE

Hereâ€™s a framework to tell which agents will disrupt

Weâ€™re all hyped about Agentic AI where agents that can do things, not just say things. But how do you separate the game-changers from the nice-to-haves and the nice-to-sees?

Hereâ€™s a simple framework to assess impact. Letâ€™s call it the AAA framework based on how each category is named:

Category 1: Autonomous AI (High Impact)

These systems operate independently, making decisions without human input. They impact the entire organization and replace the need for thousands of manual actions.

Examples:
 â€¢ AI-driven customer support resolving millions of queries
 â€¢ Inventory systems that detect demand spikes and restock autonomously
 â€¢ Self-healing cloud infrastructure: detects, patches, spins up backup clusters
 â€¢ Dynamic ad engines that test, optimize, and reallocate budget in real time
 â€¢ Autonomous content moderation balancing culture, regulation, and safety

Category 2: Augmentative AI (Medium Impact)

AI here collaborates with humans and works across departments, but isnâ€™t fully in control. Itâ€™s valuable at scale, especially when validation or human oversight is still needed.

Examples:
 â€¢ Insurance or employee claims processing with auto-approvals + fraud checks
 â€¢ AI screening CVs, scheduling interviews, and conducting basic assessments
 â€¢ Virtual advisors suggesting procurement or retail decisions in meetings
 â€¢ AI-assisted fraud detection in satellite or CCTV feeds across large projects

Category 3: Assistive AI (Low Impact)

Focused on individual productivity, these tools donâ€™t scale across the org. Their impact is real, but hard to measure or justify at a business level.

Examples:
 â€¢ Tools like Cursor or GitHub Copilot helping devs write faster
 â€¢ Chatbots or internal search agents for retrieving org knowledge

So what really disrupts?
AI that takes action autonomously and impacts the organization, not just the individual. Thatâ€™s the leap from â€œsmart assistantâ€ to â€œsilent operator.â€

Where does your companyâ€™s AI sit today?

#AgenticAI #AutonomousAI #GenAI #FutureOfWork #AIstrategy #Productivity #AIinBusiness #LinkedInAI

However, if I use the same "Oil" analogy:
ğŸ¯ 
ğŸ”¹ What good is a vast oil reserve if it takes years to locate and extract it?
ğŸ”¹ What if your refinery (read: data infra, dashboards, BI tools, legacy workflows) is outdated?
ğŸ”¹ What if product or business team need insights today, but due to legacy system data can be extracted only after a quarter?

This is true in many companies across the spectrum:

#4: Delivered too late to matter.

This results into - lost opportunities, delayed use of data, and worst of all decisions taken - which are not based on solid data.

content:
As an HR professional, I've come to realize that this role is not just about fulfilling responsibilities, but about embodying a set of values and principles that prioritize people and organizational growth. Effective HR practice requires a unique blend of emotional intelligence, business acumen, and strategic thinking. It's about understanding the intricacies of human behavior, navigating complex situations, and finding solutions that balance individual needs with organizational objectives.

Throughout my career, I've had the privilege of working with leaders who require guidance on delivering constructive feedback, supporting employees through significant life changes, and developing policies that promote a positive and productive work environment. In these moments, I've learned that HR is not just about enforcing rules or following procedures, but about being a catalyst for growth, empathy, and accountability.

The most impactful HR professionals are those who can read between the lines, shape organizational culture, and model the behaviors they expect from others. They understand that HR is about putting people first, while also driving business results.

content:
Power BI and Dimensional Modeling

Should I learn Dimensional Modeling?

Dimensional modeling is widely accepted as the dominant technique for data warehousing and business intelligence due to several key reasons:

Intuitive Design
Optimized for Query Performance
Flexibility and Scalability
Agility in Development
Ease of Maintenance
Support for Analytical Applications
Industry Best Practices

Power BI and Dimensional Modeling
By understanding dimensional modeling principles, you can effectively design and implement robust Power BI models. This empowers you to create powerful and insightful visualizations, reports, and dashboards that drive data-driven decision-making

So, should you learn dimensional modeling? Absolutely! It's a valuable skill that will enhance your ability to work with Power BI and other BI tools, enabling you to unlock the full potential of your data.

Get Up! Stand Up! Start Your Learning!

content:
In todayâ€™s interconnected world, effective leadership doesnâ€™t stop at national or cultural borders.
While Diversity & Inclusion may no longer be a formal mandate in some U.S. corporate agendas, its value has never been more strategic. Why?
Because real growth lies in reaching and understanding people, not just managing them.

â¡ï¸ Over 80 million people in North America are first- or second-generation immigrants.
â¡ï¸They buy, build, invest, and shape culture â€” but are often spoken to in ways that donâ€™t reflect who they are.
This isnâ€™t about leaving English behind â€” it will always be the dominant language of business.

 Itâ€™s about recognizing the people behind the metrics and unlocking the untapped potential that comes from culturally fluent leadership and communication.
âœ”ï¸  McKinsey found that companies with cultural diversity in leadership are 36% more likely to be profitable.
 âœ”ï¸  Forbes showed that 85% of executives believe diversity drives innovation.
 âœ”ï¸  Gallup reports that inclusive leadership boosts employee engagement by 22%.
But multicultural success requires more than language. It demands leaders who:
Understand individualism vs. collectivism
Adapt communication styles, incentives, and trust-building techniques
See inclusion not as a checkbox, but as a bridge to market growth, loyalty, and resilience
As someone who has worked across Canadian and Latin American markets for over 15 years, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand that culture-conscious leadership isnâ€™t soft â€” itâ€™s smart.
If we want to lead in a world shaped by migration, global trade, and cross-cultural exchange, we must build businesses that reflect the people they serve.

So I ask:
 Are we speaking to communities or simply around them?

content:
Sales Data Mart Development Project | SSIS & SQL Server
As part of my training in the Business Intelligence track at ITI, I developed a hands-on project to build a complete Sales Data Mart using Microsoft technologies, applying real-world ETL and Data Warehousing concepts.
ğŸ“Œ Project Highlights:
ğŸ”¹ Designed a Data Mart using the Star Schema model consisting of:
Fact_Sales
Dim_Date
Dim_Customer
Dim_Product
Dim_Territory
ğŸ”¹ Implemented ETL processes using SSIS, including:
Extracting data from multiple sources (Excel Files and SQL Server)
Applying transformation logic using:
Lookup, Derived Column, Merge Join
Slowly Changing Dimension (SCD Type 1 & Type 2)
ğŸ”¹ Loaded data into SQL Server Data Warehouse using OLE DB Destination
ğŸ›  Technologies Used:
SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS)
Microsoft SQL Server
Excel
Data Warehousing Concepts
Star Schema Modeling
ETL Process Design

ğŸ“‚ The full project is documented and available on GitHub:
ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/gzvXJ49a

On 4 July, the European Commission sent a clear message to the tech world:

â€œThere is no stop the clock. There is no grace period. There is no pause.â€

Despite coordinated lobbying from over 100 major players, including Google and Meta, the AI Act is moving forward. Fast.

ğŸ“ Whatâ€™s already in effect?

Bans on unlawful AI use
Mandatory AI literacy for providers (since Feb 2025)

ğŸ“ Whatâ€™s next?

August 2025 â†’ General-purpose AI (GPAI), including open-source and API-based systems, must comply
August 2026 â†’ High-risk AI systems in HR, healthcare, education, finance, and law enforcement come under enforcement

This isnâ€™t just compliance.
This is operational risk at infrastructure scale.

Yet many organisations still:
âš ï¸ Lack audit trails for AI models
âš ï¸ Use models trained on non-compliant data
âš ï¸ Havenâ€™t classified risks or built governance
âš ï¸ Deploy without legal or ethical oversight

Boards and CxOs, take note:
The AI Act doesnâ€™t just regulate systems, it puts you in the frame. With documentation, registration, and penalties.

ğŸ’¡ If your AI system touches hiring, credit, health, or compliance, itâ€™s not a prototype. Itâ€™s a liability.

This is GDPR-level accountability, but deeper, because this time, the system makes decisions.

Why I Started Coding Again After 15 Years in Leadership

In my current role leading technology across luxury retail, real estate, and investments, much of my focus is on strategy, platforms, and transformation at scale.

But recently, I took a step backâ€”and decided to build something myself.
I developed a simple iOS app to manage in-store customer queues. What started as a side experiment quickly showed real impact:

â€“ Sales executives now have a live view of waiting customers
â€“ Customers get notified automatically when it's their turn
â€“ Store managers can track service times and shift coverage in real-time

The result?

Shorter wait times. Smoother handovers. Higher customer satisfaction.
I built the app using AI-enhanced development toolsâ€”not to replace the team, but to better understand the new pace of innovation and how these tools could help us move faster.

What surprised me wasnâ€™t just the speed, but howÂ coding again changed the way I lead:

âœ… I could empathise with what developers face
âœ… I made better architectural decisions
âœ… I spotted low-effort, high-impact wins that could have been missed

As technology leaders, weâ€™re expected to drive change. But sometimes, the best way to lead transformation is to roll up our sleeves and build something.
In a world shaped by AI,Â technical curiosity is becoming a core leadership skill.

What does ethical AI look like in practice? ğŸ¤” 

As AI systems become more powerful and embedded in society, itâ€™s no longer enough to ask what we can build; we must also ask how we can build responsibly.

Thatâ€™s why the UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence (November 2021) is so important:
Itâ€™s the first-ever global standard for ethical AI practices, rooted in the belief that human rights, dignity, and oversight must guide every AI system we design.

Hereâ€™s a quick breakdown:

Core Values

â¡ï¸ Human Rights & Dignity
â¡ï¸ Diversity & Inclusiveness
â¡ï¸ Peaceful, Interconnected Societies
â¡ï¸ Environmental & Ecosystem Flourishing

Core Principles

â¡ï¸ Do No Harm & Proportionality
â¡ï¸ Safety, Security, Privacy
â¡ï¸ Transparency & Explainability
â¡ï¸ Human Oversight
â¡ï¸ Fairness, Non-Discrimination, Accountability & Responsibility
â¡ï¸ Multi-Stakeholder Collaboration
â¡ï¸ Literacy, Sustainability

Key Implementation Areas (Policy Areas)

â¡ï¸ Data Governance
â¡ï¸ Environment & Ecosystems
â¡ï¸ Gender & Culture
â¡ï¸ Education & Research
â¡ï¸ Communication & Information
â¡ï¸ Labour, Health, & Wellbeing

Implementation Methods

â¡ï¸ Readiness Assessment
â¡ï¸ Ethical Impact Assessment

ğŸ” TL;DR â€“ Why This Matters

âœ… AI must serve people and the planet, not just profits.
âœ… Ethical AI is no longer optional. It's urgent.
âœ… Impact assessments and governance frameworks must be incorporated into the (product) lifecycle from the start.
âœ… We need multi-stakeholder voices at the table to ensure ethical AI frameworks are diverse, inclusive, and adaptive.
âœ… Ethical AI policies and practices must be tied to clear systems of impact measurement and continuous assessment that allow for improvement over time.

Want to go deeper? You can read the full UNESCO Recommendation here: https://lnkd.in/dwUhxAKA
Or read the summary version here: https://lnkd.in/dsskMuag

Is your organization intentionally building ethical AI practices into its lifecycle, or is it doing so reactively? ğŸ¤”

content:
2.5 months ago, I stepped into the real world as a first-year MBA student from IIM Ranchi, excited, nervous, and completely unaware of the whirlwind that awaited me.

What began as a daunting challenge building an AI-led, zero-human-intervention automation system for our social media news posting quickly turned into a steep learning curve filled with sleepless nights, failed attempts, and invaluable lessons.

Iâ€™ve already shared that story. But what followed next made this experience truly transformative.

After completing my first automation, I was introduced to something even more exciting - AI agents, Telegram bots, and process workflow automations.

The problems I was asked to solve werenâ€™t textbook cases.
They were ambiguous, undefined, and open-ended â€” exactly how challenges in fast-growing tech startups often are.

And this is where one of the most powerful lessons from Rishabh Gupta  came in:
â€œBreak down the problem. Solve one part at a time. Solutions will follow.â€

Taking that approach forward, I learned to:
	â€¢	Structure ambiguous problems
	â€¢	Design effective, AI-backed solutions
	â€¢	Implement workflow automations using tools like Make.com, Zapier, custom Python scripts, and AI APIs
	â€¢	Build Telegram bots for automating investor relations and Web3 project monitoring

Slowly, I moved from someone trying to understand tech to someone confidently crafting solutions.
Thatâ€™s when I was given a title Iâ€™ll always remember â€” Solution Architect.

What makes this journey even more special is the culture at TDeFi | TradeDog Token Growth Studio 
A place where curiosity is encouraged, learning is constant, and no idea is too small to be heard. My internship, initially slated for 2 months, was happily extended by 15 days â€” simply because I didnâ€™t want to stop learning, and the team made sure I didnâ€™t have to.

A heartfelt thank you to:
Rishabh Gupta  â€” for the trust, guidance, and for teaching me how to navigate uncertainty

Mansi Bhargava  and Vaibhav Singhâš¡  for your unwavering support, feedback, and mentorship

Grateful for this experience. Hereâ€™s to the next adventure.

It all started with a rough AI prototype, simple, but it worked. The real breakthrough came when we realized: 
ğŸ‘‰ AI isnâ€™t just about the model, itâ€™s about how you talk to it.

We were experimenting with speech-to-text tools, using APIs and trying different ways to analyze transcripts. It wasnâ€™t perfect, and the results were inconsistent.

The turning point came when we figured out that >>> effective prompting made all the difference.

At first, it felt like we were trying to make AI bend to our will, but it wasnâ€™t giving us the results we wanted. It was frustrating.

We discovered that writing the right prompts was a skill of its own. Once we figured out how to communicate with AI, the results became consistent, and our prototype began solving real problems for our clients.

Our first prototype was basic, but it worked. We tested it with real data and saw it solving client issues. We embraced the journey - iterating, experimenting, and learning from each failure.

What I learned: 
âœ… Understanding how to use technology is just as important as having the right tools.

content:
Michael Carr Associate Professor, Emergency Medicine at Emory School of Medicine, reports, "as soon as you take a rural hospital out of a local community, patients may suddenly need to drive much further to receive medical care.

Professor Carr has used grant funding awarded grant funding by HHS to create "Prehospital and Ambulatory Virtual Emergency Services". (PAVES) to provide advanced telemedicine diagnostic technology to EMT crews.

There are still technological challenges to overcome. The technology must function reliably in a moving ambulance, on highways, and on bumpy roads and in good and bad weather. Digital transformation of emergency medicine can't fix the whole problem but is a step in the right direction.

content:
AI isnâ€™t here to do your job, itâ€™s here to dismantle the version of yourself that only mattered because others had to go through you.

AI isnâ€™t coming for your job. Itâ€™s coming for your sense of self.

We keep talking about AI like itâ€™s a tool problem.
Itâ€™s not. Itâ€™s an identity crisis.

Because AI doesnâ€™t just change how we work. It changes what leadership means. And most people in charge arenâ€™t ready for that.

The quiet unraveling of control

It started during the pandemic. Leaders lost visibility and, with it, their default source of power. Microsoftâ€™s 2023 Work Trend Index showed 85 percent of leaders didnâ€™t trust that people were productive if they couldnâ€™t see them. Thatâ€™s not a workflow problem. Thatâ€™s a control problem.

Now AI is speeding up the breakdown. It doesnâ€™t ask for sign-off. It doesnâ€™t care about hierarchy. It just moves. And the leadership model built on being the decider is showing its cracks.

The real threat is irrelevance

A 2024 BCG study found 89 percent of execs believe AI gives them a competitive edge. Only 36 percent have adopted it at scale. That gap isnâ€™t about the tech. Itâ€™s about fear.

Fear of no longer being needed. Fear of becoming just another node in a smarter system.

What new leadership demands

Let go of being the bottleneck
Youâ€™re not powerful because people need your sign-off. Youâ€™re powerful when they donâ€™t.

Trade authority for enablement
Your job is to design systems that work without you. Not hover over them.

Rely on data, not dominance
If the model is right and your instinct says no, you better have a reason.

Detach identity from control
If your value is rooted in being in charge, AI is going to feel like erosion. Itâ€™s not. Itâ€™s a reset.

This moment is personal

The real transformation isnâ€™t digital. Itâ€™s psychological. AI is revealing which leaders are willing to evolve and which are just holding on.

So ask yourself, are you building the future or defending the past? Because the room is changing. The pace is changing. And relevance doesnâ€™t wait for permission

Hereâ€™s how to turn common damaging phrases into growth-focused dialogue:

âŒ â€œYou need to work harder.â€

Instead say: 
â€œHereâ€™s how you can be more effective in your role.â€

âŒ â€œYouâ€™re not meeting expectations.â€

Instead say: 
â€œLetâ€™s review expectations and how we can bridge the gap.â€

âŒ â€œThis was disappointing.â€

Instead say: 
â€œI see areas for growthâ€¦ letâ€™s talk about improvements.â€

âŒ â€œYou need to improve.â€

Instead say: 
â€œHereâ€™s whatâ€™s working well and what could be stronger.â€

âŒ â€œYouâ€™re not leadership material.â€

Instead say: 
â€œHere are some skills to develop for future leadership roles.â€

âŒ â€œYou always struggle with this.â€

Instead say: 
â€œThis is an opportunity to improveâ€¦ hereâ€™s how.â€

âŒ â€œThis needs to be perfect next time.â€

Instead say: 
â€œLetâ€™s set realistic steps for continuous progress.â€

âŒ â€œYou should already know this.â€

Instead say: 
â€œLetâ€™s go over this so you feel more confident next time.â€

âŒ â€œYour performance isnâ€™t good enough.â€

Instead say: 
â€œHereâ€™s what youâ€™re doing wellâ€¦ letâ€™s focus on whatâ€™s next.â€

âŒ â€œThereâ€™s no room for negotiation.â€

Instead say: 
â€œIâ€™d love to hear your thoughts on this and discuss further.â€

After working with hundreds of managers and reviewing thousands of appraisal conversations, I can tell you this: people donâ€™t remember every word, they remember how
the conversation made them feel. 

One careless phrase can stall someoneâ€™s growth. One thoughtful one can unlock their potential.

These conversations shape your culture...

They influence retention, motivation, and trust. 

Get them wrong, and you lose performance. Get them right, and you build the kind of team that grows stronger after every review.

ğŸ§  Remember; The words you choose in a review will 
echo long after the meeting ends.

Say less about what went wrong, focus more on what comes next. Clarity drives progress. Respect fuels commitment.

Which of these phrases do you hear too often?

content:
Listened to a superb speech by Sridhar Vembu on AI at #Zoholics. 

Here are four things I found super useful.

1. Use the "Socratic Method" for AI Research.
Don't accept the first AI answer. Engage it in debate. Sridhar's technique: ask an AI to generate information, then start a new session and ask it to critique its own work. For even better results, pit two different AIs against each otherâ€”take one response and ask the other to criticize it. He calls this a "very productive way to learn about a topic."

2. Identify High-Risk "No-Go" Zones for AI.
Understand where AI needs intense human oversight. Sridhar's "big no" examples: never let AI generate code and push it directly to production; don't use AI for legal or regulatory documents. AI invents facts and non-existent case law, which has gotten lawyers into serious trouble.

3. Find Truth in Regulatory Filings, Not Marketing.
Want the real story about a competitor? Study their SEC or SEBI filings. Sridhar says this is the "one place they have to control the marketing bullshit." A great strategy for accurate business intelligence.

4. Verification is the Real Bottleneck.
AI can generate 10,000 lines of code in minutes, but "no human can ever go through it to verify" it in comparable time. Sridhar notes the programming principle that "reading code is known to be much tougher than writing code in the first place." This understanding helps set realistic expectations for AI productivity and tells us why it needs human oversight.

content:
Everyone's building the same three AI products.

AI SDR. AI meeting notes. AI chatbot.

10,000 startups. 3 ideas. Zero taste.

I see pitch decks every week. "We're like Gong but with AI." "We're Salesforce with a chatbot." "We're the AI version of [insert any SaaS tool]."

Last week, a customer asked me for call recording features. I told him straight up:

"I am NOT a call recorder. You are offending me with these questions. I'm here to serve your customers."

He looked confused. Like I'd just told him I don't believe in gravity.

That's the problem. We're so obsessed with making AI do what humans used to do, we forgot to imagine what it could do that humans never could.

Take customer success. Everyone's racing to build AI that writes better follow-up emails. But what if the problem isn't the email quality? What if it's that we're sending emails at all?

What if instead of 10 touchpoints over 3 months, you could have one perfect interaction at exactly the right moment?

What if instead of quarterly business reviews, you had continuous intelligence flowing between you and your customer?

What if instead of "scaling" customer success, we reimagined it entirely?

This is what taste looks like in the AI era. Not copying what exists and adding a chatbot. But questioning every assumption about how business works.

The winners won't be the ones who build AI versions of old software. They'll be the ones who use AI to build things that were never possible before.

That's the difference between following and leading. Between copying and creating.

Between having taste and having none.

Stop building better note-takers. Start building better businesses.

content:
Generative AI is no longer a futuristic conceptâ€”itâ€™s a transformative force reshaping how enterprises operate, innovate, and scale. However, its real potential can only be unlocked when implemented strategically within the broader enterprise architecture.

ğŸ” Why Gen AI Needs a Structured Approach

While generative AI offers immense valueâ€”from content automation to improved decision-makingâ€”it also brings significant architectural challenges:
- Misalignment with business objectives
- Risk of silos and integration complexity
- Data inconsistencies and governance concerns
- Ethical risks, security vulnerabilities, and model bias
- Uncertainty around scalability and interoperability

ğŸ›ï¸ Enterprise Architecture as the Foundation for AI
To truly harness Gen AI, organizations must take a strategic and holistic approach. Enterprise architecture helps:
- Align AI initiatives with business goals
- Enable seamless integration across existing systems
- Build scalable, interoperable, and compliant frameworks
- Ensure robust data governance and security
- Define ethical boundaries and regulatory standards

âš™ï¸ Key Considerations for Integration
When embedding Gen AI into the enterprise ecosystem, leaders must account for:
- Data Readiness: High-quality, structured, and relevant data is non-negotiable
- Infrastructure: Scalable and distributed environments to support model complexity
- Security: Encryption, access controls, and privacy protection
- User Enablement: Training and adoption strategies for cross-functional teams
- Cost & Risk: Total cost of ownership and potential AI-driven risks

ğŸ§­ A Strategic Roadmap for Implementation
1. Align AI with Business Strategy
2. Assess Organizational Readiness
3. Prepare Quality Data & Select Suitable Models
4. Integrate with Existing EA Systems
5. Establish Ethics, Security, and Compliance Protocols
6. Monitor, Optimize & Foster Adoption Continuously

In the age of intelligent automation, integrating Gen AI isnâ€™t just a tech initiativeâ€”itâ€™s an enterprise-wide transformation that demands clarity, governance, and architectural foresight.

content:
The Silent Burnout: When Explaining Becomes Exhausting

As a 36-year-old entrepreneur with diagnosed autistic traits, I've found one of the greatest burdens of building Circular Refining isn't the challenge of innovation, but the constant, repetitive demand to explain what we do. This goes hand-in-hand with the endless task of keeping our business plan, investor data room, and financial models perpetually up-to-date.

Honestly, it's a significant personal cause of founder burnout for me. The mental energy required for consistent, detailed articulation, especially when it's iterative updates to complex documents like financial models, is immense. It's truly challenging to find adequate support for founders like myself in this area. While AI is making incredible strides, it's still not quite "there" with the more in-depth, nuanced tools needed to truly automate and simplify complex financial modeling and data room management.

I believe there's a real need for better solutions and more understanding in the startup ecosystem for founders who experience these particular challenges. Has anyone else felt this way? What strategies or tools have you found helpful in managing this burden?

content:
Yesterday, I joined a thought-provoking day at the Progressive Tech Summit, hosted by Arden Strategies and Startup Coalition, where policymakers, founders, and technologists gathered to shape the UKâ€™s long-term role in global tech.

For me, it was about the â€œFuture of Workâ€ roundtable, where the narrative often promises opportunity, yet we know the reality paints a more complex picture. Bringing my lens as a Fractional CXO and founder working at the intersection of innovation, inclusion, and organisational change, this made for a great discussion!

ğŸ’¬ Yet, the big question of the day was:

ğ–ğ¡ğšğ­ ğğ¨ğğ¬ ğš ğ©ğ«ğ¨ğ ğ«ğğ¬ğ¬ğ¢ğ¯ğ ğ­ğğœğ¡ ğ©ğ¨ğ¥ğ¢ğœğ² ğšğœğ­ğ®ğšğ¥ğ¥ğ² ğ¥ğ¨ğ¨ğ¤ ğ¥ğ¢ğ¤ğ?

Hereâ€™s what stood out for me:

âœ¨ Tech alone wonâ€™t close the gap.
We talk about AI as a great equaliser, but without equitable access to infrastructure, education, and tools, we risk widening the digital divide. Progressive policy ğ¦ğ®ğ¬ğ­ prioritise funding, access, and inclusion at every level.

ğŸ¤ AI isnâ€™t just a threat to jobs, itâ€™s an opportunity to amplify human potential.
We need to shift the narrative from â€œreplacementâ€ to â€œaugmentation.â€ Letâ€™s talk more about 10x'ing teams: ğ’‰ğ’–ğ’ğ’‚ğ’ğ’” ğ’‘ğ’ğ’–ğ’” ğ‘¨ğ‘°, ğ’ğ’ğ’• ğ’‰ğ’–ğ’ğ’‚ğ’ğ’” ğ’—ğ’” ğ‘¨ğ‘°.

ğŸ“ Thereâ€™s an appetite to invest beyond Londonâ€¦ but no clear plan to nurture talent. Regions like Manchester, Leeds, Yorkshire and Newcastle were repeatedly spotlighted, yet investment alone isnâ€™t enough. We need deliberate strategies to attract, retain, and grow talent in these areas.

ğŸšº Women and underrepresented groups are still missing from the AI conversation. AI requires pattern recognition, critical thinking, and nuanced skills, all of which women excel in. Yet the sector remains male-dominated. Without intentional inclusion, weâ€™re building biased futures.

ğŸ“‰ 96% of enterprise AI users donâ€™t maximise its value or measure ROI.
This isnâ€™t just a tech gap, itâ€™s a leadership one. We need to empower leaders to experiment, upskill, and build AI-literate organisations.

ğŸ’­ I left inspired, but clear-eyed. Thereâ€™s momentum, but also a risk that our policy vision stops at aspiration without practical, inclusive action.

ğŸ“¢ So, Iâ€™m asking you: What should government, business, and tech leaders be doing right now to make this vision a reality?

In the early 1900s, cars were luxury items â€” handcrafted slowly and priced based on the labor it took to make them.

Then Henry Ford introduced the moving assembly line in 1913.

Suddenly, a car could be built in 90 minutes instead of 12 hours.

Ford didnâ€™t price the car by the time it took.
He priced it by the value it delivered â€” access, freedom, scale.

The same shift is happening in software today.

With AI, products that used to take 3â€“6 months to build can now be created in weeks â€” even days.

So why are we still charging for dev hours?

content:
ğŸš€ Agentic AI: The Next Evolution in AI-Driven Workforces
By 2028, one-third of enterprise apps will feature agentic AI, up from less than 1% in 2024. (Gartner 2025 Strategic Technology Trend Study). That stat alone can get every tech leaderâ€™s attention.
Agentic AI is no longer science fiction. Itâ€™s a strategic imperative.
ğŸ¤– What Is Agentic AI?
Agentic AI refers to goal-driven software entities that can autonomously plan, decide, and act. Unlike traditional AI that responds to prompts, agentic AI acts on its own initiative â€” analyzing data, making decisions, and triggering workflows â€” all while aligning with organizational goals.
Think of it as a digital co-worker that never sleeps, doesnâ€™t need breaks, and continuously learns.
ğŸŒŸ Why It Matters
Agentic AI marks a leap forward in productivity and decision-making. It will:
Augment human teams, managing complex projects via natural language
Break down silos, connecting data and workflows across systems
Improve CX, automating personalized, intelligent interactions
Accelerate insights, making decisions while you sleep
This isnâ€™t about replacing jobs â€” itâ€™s about empowering talent to focus on what truly matters.

âš ï¸ What to Watch Out For
As with any disruptive tech, agentic AI brings risks:
Rogue agents deployed via low-code tools
Poor data quality leading to poor decisions
Security vulnerabilities like prompt injection or AI-generated malware
Resistance from teams fearing loss of control
Governance, transparency, and trust must be built into every agent.
ğŸ”‘ How to Prepare
Start small, with well-scoped, high-value use cases
Redesign workflows with agents as primary actors, humans in strategic loops
Establish clear guardrails â€” legal, ethical, and operational
Treat AI agents like team members â€” give them roles, measure outcomes, refine
What This Means for Business Leaders
To stay competitive, organizations must begin bridging the AI agency gap now, i.e.
âœ… Moving from task automation to goal execution
 âœ… Investing in AI governance and risk management
 âœ… Rethinking talent strategies to support AI fluency and oversight
 âœ… Designing for human-agent collaboration, not replacement

ğŸ“Œ Final Thought
Agentic AI isn't just another tool â€” it's a fundamental shift in how work gets done. The organizations that get ahead of this wave will see outsized gains in speed, scale, and strategy.

content:
Project Title:
ğŸš€ Digital Clock/Counter System using Logic ICs â€“ Proteus Simulation

1. Project Description:
In this project, we designed and simulated a 6-digit digital clock/counter system using sequential logic circuits on Proteus. This system effectively demonstrates how fundamental digital components can be combined to build real-time applications such as clocks or counters.

2.Functionality:
This circuit counts seconds, minutes, and hours in real-time. The counter increments every second, and the count is displayed in real-time on 7-segment displays using proper BCD decoding.

3. Key Components Used:

74LS90 â€“ Decade Counter ICs (for counting up to 60 seconds/minutes and 24 hours)

 74LS47 â€“ BCD to 7-segment Decoder (for driving displays)

Common Cathode 7-Segment Displays â€“ For visual output

Clock Pulse Generator â€“ To simulate real-time ticking

 Resistors â€“ 100kÎ© for debouncing or timing logic

Logic Gates (7498 NAND) â€“ To manage logic control/reset

 Proteus Software â€“ For simulation and validation


3. What Makes It Interesting:

Purely built using logic gates and counter ICs, without any microcontroller.

Modular and scalable design â€“ can be extended to include AM/PM, alarm functionality, or even date counters.

Real-time simulation shows the practical usage of digital electronics in embedded systems and automation.


ğŸŒŸ Why This Project? This was a great opportunity to strengthen foundational digital logic concepts, simulate realistic timing behavior, and prepare for more advanced microcontroller-based projects.

Here are the Proteus simulation and implementation of that circuit in bread board

content:
She bootstrapped a unicorn for 12 yearsâ€”with no salary and two kids.

In 2001, Therese Tucker was a single mom of two. 

She was also CTO at a Fortune 500 company. 

But inside the boardroom, all she saw were middle-aged white men collecting awards. 

She knew sheâ€™d hit a ceiling and that sheâ€™d never be CEO unless she built the company herself.

So she cashed out her nest egg, nearly raided her kidsâ€™ college funds, and launched BlackLine from scratch.

Their first product was a wealth management software. 

It flopped.

But Therese was humble enough to pivot when a customer pointed out the real opportunityâ€¦

An early client, The Bank of Nebraska, called one day in a panic: they were trying to reconcile tens of thousands of accounts trapped in a massive spreadsheet. 

Therese took the $10K job, built a quick tool to fix it, and realized no one was solving this pain point.

So she invented a new category: cloud-based accounting automation.

She went to raise money but only got lowball offers and condescension. 

Instead, she bootstrapped her way to $38M in revenue by 2013â€”serving clients like Coca-Cola, SiriusXM, SunTrust, GoDaddy, and Costco.

And when youâ€™re spending your own money, you get good at it.

Therese used frequent flyer miles to buy plane tickets. 

Waited until the last minute to get cheaper booths at trade shows. 

And when payroll was tight, she begged friends for $30K to bridge the gapâ€”because she couldnâ€™t get paid until her clients did.

She didnâ€™t take a salary until year six. 

And when she finally did, it was $30K. A tenth of what she made at SunGard. 
And she was thrilled.

In 2016, she took BlackLine public at a $1.5B valuation.

By 2018, the company had over 800 employees and 2,400 customers.

By 2020, her stake was worth $370M.

Therese doesnâ€™t look like a typical Silicon Valley founder.

She wears a black hoodie, pastel jeans, and has pink hair.

A style choice that started as a marketing dare but stuck as her signature.

Ultimately, Therese built BlackLine on boring software for a boring function. 

Because she knew that sometimes, the best businesses are the ones no one else thinks are interesting.
