How I hacked the algorithm to gain 5,000 followers in one day:

Just kidding. I didnâ€™t. I just write. âœ¨

Thatâ€™s been the goal from the start: to refine my voice, sharpen my perspective, challenge outdated norms in corporate America & beyond, and keep growing as a writer.

Some posts land. Some donâ€™t. And thatâ€™s fine! Iâ€™m not optimizing for performance and Iâ€™m not trying to gain a million followers. I want to focus on the kind of work that actually moves things forward.

Posting on LinkedIn gives me space to start. And my newsletter gives me room to go deeper. And now, ActiveCampaign powers the backend. So I can focus on the writing, while the system handles segmentation, automations, and insights that help me create better, not just more.

I donâ€™t believe in tricks or growth hacks (sorry ğŸ˜†). Just intentional writing paired with a system that supports the work I care about, so I can keep building toward the version of success I actually want.

So if youâ€™re overwhelmed by what to post, start by writing what you actually want to say. Then build the system that lets you keep doing it.

1 Anduril Industries today announced it has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Klas, a global leader in edge computing and tactical communications. The acquisition brings Klasâ€™ rugged hardware into Anduril's portfolio of autonomous systems and connected warfare capabilities.

2 Tyto Athene, LLC Athene, a federal systems integrator of mission-focused digital transformation solutions, and portfolio company of Arlington Capital Partners, has completed its acquisition of stackArmor, Inc., a premier provider of FedRAMP, FISMA/RMF, and CMMC/DFARS compliance acceleration, cloud, and security automation solutions for government agencies and the industrial base.

3 Aerovironment Inc has secured shareholder approval to acquire defense technology firm BlueHalo in an all-stock transaction valued at approximately $4.1 billion, aiming to create a diversified leader in advanced defense solutions across domains such as uncrewed systems, space technologies, electronic warfare, and AI-driven capabilities.

4 Google Distributed Cloud and GDC air-gapped have been authorized at IL6 by the United States Department of Defense to deliver secure cloud for mission critical data. 

5 Anduril Industries Chairman Trae Stephens told Bloomberg that the defense tech company has raised $2.5 billion at a $30.5 billion valuation. 

6 Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the first cloud provider to achieve FedRAMP High and Department of Defense (DoD) Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide Impact Level 4 and 5 authorizations for Anthropicâ€™s Claude and Metaâ€™s Llama AI foundation models.

7 OpenAI is joining the military. The artificial intelligence company has signed a $200 million contract with the U.S. Defense Department to provide administrative and security services as part of its new OpenAI for Government initiative. The company said its work will focus on tasks like improving how service members obtain healthcare and improving cyber defenses.

8 Google Public Sector: Google Distributed Cloud (GDC) and GDC air-gapped appliance have achieved United States Department of Defense (DoD) Impact Level 6 (IL6) authorization.

9 The Pentagon is paying OpenAI $200M for a 12-month pilot. That $200M isnâ€™t the prize - itâ€™s the price of admission. If the prototypes work, OpenAI could find itself attached to some very large, very long-term government contracts.

10 The Defense Departmentâ€™s DoD Chief Digital and Artificial Intelligence Office (CDAO) on Monday awarded four tech companies individual contracts valued at up to $200 million to provide advanced AI capabilities to address national security challenges. content:
Beautiful marketing that doesn't convert is just expensive entertainment.

I just watched a startup founder show me their $150K marketing "masterpiece"â€”beautiful website, fancy animations, cutting-edge tech stackâ€”then sheepishly admit they haven't closed a single deal in three months, and it reminded me of watching flashy basketball players who can't actually score.

[Watch this NBA funny video]

Spin moves. Crossovers. Behind-the-back passes.
Nice moves.
Ball doesn't go in.
Game still lost.

Your marketing department creates "nice things" that impress everyone except your actual customers.

I just left a meeting with a B2B startup that spent $150,000 on:
â†’ Website redesign with custom animations
â†’ Brand refresh with fancy new logo
â†’ Marketing automation tech stack
â†’ Interactive product demos
â†’ AI-powered content engine

Their pipeline? Empty.
Their bank account? Draining fast.

When I asked why prospects weren't buying, they had no idea. They'd been so busy making "nice marketing" they never bothered to understand if their audience actually cared about any of it. Turns out, they didn't.

You're using tools as substitutes for understanding.

Start by understanding:

Everything you build should directly address these answers.

Ignore vanity metrics:

Focus only on:
â†’ Qualified leads generated

I built a 7-figure real estate business with one landing page and $200/month in ads. No fancy website. No elaborate marketing. Just laser-focused messaging on a massive pain point with a clear solution. While competitors built beautiful brands that got compliments, I built a business that got customers.

The page wasn't pretty. The copy wasn't clever. But it spoke directly to what kept my prospects awake at 3am, and offered a clear path to solving it. That's all that mattered.

With over 33 years of cross-industry experience, Prakash has successfully led enterprise-wide ERP, CRM, SCM, and cloud implementations across petrochemicals, refining, packaging, utilities, and logistics sectors. Prakash holds a Chemical Engineering degree from Pune University, completed a Management Program from IIM Bangalore, and has advanced certifications in AI/ML (IIT Kanpur) and Cybersecurity (DSCI). He is also a certified Lead Auditor and ISO implementation expert (LRQA, Mumbai).

content:
ğŸš€ Thrilled to share a project our team developed during a summer training program under the mentorship of Sandeep Kaur!
 
We set out to build an end-to-end Anime Recommendation & Analytics system that combines data analysis, machine learning, SQL, and business intelligence. The idea was to tackle a simple yet fascinating problem: can we use data to predict what makes anime popular and help viewers discover underrated high-quality shows?

To solve this, we leveraged a robust tech stack: Python (Streamlit for the web app, Pandas, NumPy, Scikit-learn for ML, SHAP for explainability), SQL (MySQL) for foundational data insights, and Power BI for rich, interactive dashboards. We also used visualization libraries like Plotly, Seaborn, and Matplotlib to deeply explore genre trends, rating distributions, and correlation patterns.

The platform we built offers a range of features: an interactive dashboard to explore anime data by genre, type, and popularity; a machine learning model (Gradient Boosting Classifier) that predicts whether an anime is likely to be Unpopular or Popular/Super Hit; SHAP-based explainability to see what drives popularity; and a content-based recommendation system to suggest similar anime. We complemented this with SQL queries to surface top genres, most active users, and hidden high-rated anime, and a Power BI report to visualize overall trends.

You can explore the full project on GitHub here:
https://lnkd.in/ghFNX5gN

Weâ€™re grateful to Dr. Sandeep Kaur for her guidance and to our team for making this a truly collaborative and insightful experience. Always excited to connect with fellow data enthusiasts and discuss new ideas! ğŸš€

content:
lemlist recently crossed $34,000,000 ARR.

Here's every tool they use to run their SaaS:

Their CEO, Charles Tenot, was kind enough to share their entire tech stack â†“


1ï¸âƒ£ Content 

Their team has a combined 300,000+ LinkedIn follower count.

This includes their Founder Guillaume's account (23,000+ followers), their CEO Charles (29,000+) and other teammates such as KÃ©vin (78,000+), Lucas (57,000+), Tal (34,000+), Erwan (32,000+) & others.

They use:

- Taplio, their own platform, for content planning, ideation, and analytics.
- Figma to design infographics & carousels.

They drive 200,000+ visitors to their site every month. For SEO, they use:

- Google Search Console to monitor their website's organic performance.
- Ahrefs & Semrush to research keywords & monitor rankings.
- Storyblok as their content management system (CMS).


2ï¸âƒ£ Outbound

Since their main product, lemlist, is an all-in-one prospecting platform, it's also the tool they use most for outbound.

On top of that, they source data from several platforms:

- B2B databases: People Data Labs, Apollo, lemlist.
- Technology data: BuiltWith
- Funding data: Crunchbase

For Data enrichment, their platform includes a waterfall with the best email finders on the market (incl. Prospeo.io).

They also use a few intent signal platforms:

- LoneScale to monitor new job openings, job changes & new hires.
- Snitcher for website visitor identification.
- G2 for SaaS buyers' intent.

For 'complex' data use-cases (niche data sourcing, deep ai agentic research), they use Clay.

For deliverability, they use their email warmup platform, lemwarm.

They leverage AI models like OpenAI, Claude, Mistral AI, and use Dust, an AI agent builder.


3ï¸âƒ£ Product

They use a few software for production data, including:

- BigQuery as their data warehouse.
- Google Cloud to deploy applications.
- Holistics Data as a business intelligence platform for analytics.
- RudderStack & dbt Labs as customer data platform for data transformation.

For prototyping, they use:

- Vercel V0 for code generation & user interface.
- Replit to develop & deploy software.


4ï¸âƒ£ Funnel

They convert around ~7-8% of their 200K+ monthly visits into signups. This amounts to 15,000+ new signups every month.

To track product/website metrics, they use:
- Mixpanel
- Google Analytics

To extract, transform, load & synchronise data across every department, they useÂ Hightouch, which is what's called a 'reverse ETL platform'.

Then, their marketing stack includes:
- Customer.io (for email marketing)
- Default (for lead routing)
- Webflow (website)


5ï¸âƒ£ Sales

Their sales team, led by Yann Guilleux, has been on fire lately.

We're talking $685K in ARR closed last month.

Their sales stack includes:
- Hyperline for contracts, custom quotes, invoicing.
- Spoke for meetings recordings/transcripts.
- lemcal to schedule meetings.
- HubSpot as their CRM.

I'm running out of space given the number of tools, haha!

content:
10,000 Accelerators delivered!

I donâ€™t post often on LinkedInâ€¦ so forgive me on this oneâ€¦ itâ€™s long!

Last month our team delivered our 10,000th Impact accelerator.Â This team focuses on technical and UX topics, helping our customers get the most from their investment and driving their success.

This a huge achievementâ€¦ not long ago 100/month was a daunting task; now we're regularly doing 50 per day.Â Volume is just the tip of the iceberg though to this story.

This took a village, and what an amazing village it is.

The team that creates the accelerators under the leadership of Chris Akens has driven the Technical Accelerator catalog from 6 accelerators at launch to over 60 today.

The amazing consultants under the leadership of Boris BÃ¼chel, Damy Adesanya, Richard Rees and Bill Quinn.Â They earn stellar customer satisfaction scores, move the needle on adoption and health, and the feedback from Impact customers large and small is amazing.

And then there are the supporting casts in Impact product teams, engineering and business operations, and cloud automation that help us drive this elite level execution.

And the CSMs and squads that partner with us every day to help find the right solutions for their Impact customers.

And last but definitely not least: our customers who give us and the consultants feedback on how we can constantly improve and what we can offer next.Â Once a customer starts "using us" they keep coming back for more!

Is that a village or a small city?

But if you ask me what I love mostâ€¦ it's this:Â the culture in the team and the diversity. 

The team is brimming with people that arenâ€™t just talented, but they have a DNA of extreme helpfulness: win as a team, wow our customers, create belonging and stay hungry and humble are on display every day in every one of our hubs and around the globe. Oh, and minor note: they have over 1,000 ServiceNow certifications between them!

And the diversity? So many ways to look at that: we have 41 nationalities represented across 120 people just for starters!Â Â The backgrounds range from people with over a dozen years direct ServiceNow experience to early-in-career, from industry veterans to graduates from RiseUp and our veterans programs, from people with AI degrees to psychologists, a marine biologist, and some very talented musicians â€“ they all bring their own strengths to the table and make beautiful music together. Itâ€™s hard work here but with these awesome colleagues, an amazing mission, and a product that delights our customers â€¦ it is honestly fun!

content:
Federal Reserve Goes Live on ISO 20022

As U.S. payment rails modernize, the Federal Reserveâ€™s adoption of ISO 20022 is more than a compliance milestoneâ€”it signals a structural shift in how financial data will flow, be interpreted, and leveraged.

The 2025 Diary of Consumer Payment Choice offers timely insights into the underlying behavioral layer:

- 48 payments per consumer per month in 2024â€”a record high, driven largely by credit and remote transactions.
- Credit cards now account for 35% of all payment volume, up from 18% in 2016.
- Mobile payments reached 23% of all transactions, with 45% of 18â€“24-year-olds using phones as their primary payment interface.
- Cash remains resilient, holding steady at 7 payments per monthâ€”a four-year plateau that may represent a structural â€œfloorâ€ in consumer behavior.

Income and age remain key differentiators in instrument choiceâ€”lower-income and older consumers remain disproportionately cash-reliant.

Why does this matter in the context of ISO 20022?

Because payment modernization isnâ€™t just about message formats. Itâ€™s about how institutions ingest, structure, and act on high-fidelity data across diverse consumer behaviors and fragmented front-end channels.

The Fedâ€™s ISO 20022 implementation opens the door for:

- Data-rich reconciliation and real-time exception handling
- Consistent semantic interpretation across ACH, wire, RTP, and FedNow
- Downstream AI capabilities, including contextual risk scoring and advisory automation
- Enhanced auditability and cross-border alignment, especially with the Swift Transaction Manager and CBPR+ migration

But this shift also surfaces a critical tension:Â 
Legacy consumer behaviors and emerging data standards are not always in sync.

To bridge that gap, institutions must move beyond format translationâ€”and build capabilities that unify ISO-native and non-ISO inputs, support hybrid orchestration models, and unlock intelligence from message payloads in real time.

As ISO 20022 becomes the backbone of global payment infrastructures, even long-established ACH networks are evolving to align with structured data principles.

ISO 20022 isnâ€™t just about complianceâ€”itâ€™s about enabling automation, interoperability, and insight.Â  

Nth Exception Federal Reserve Financial Services

content:
AI Workloads Are Reshaping Data Center Infrastructure: What You Need to Know

Artificial Intelligence is transforming every industry, from finance to healthcare, driving innovation and unlocking new business models. But as AI adoption accelerates, the pressure on data center infrastructure is reaching unprecedented levels. Traditional facilities, once optimized for predictable enterprise workloads, are now being pushed to their limits by the demands of high-performance AI computing.

Key Challenges and Shifts:

Rising Rack Densities: AI hardware, especially GPU clusters, requires much higher power per rack. Standard deployments of 10-15kW/rack are being replaced by AI racks drawing 40kW or more, with some experimental setups exceeding 100kW. This stresses every part of the power chain, from UPS systems to facility switchgear.

Cooling Innovations: Conventional air cooling is no longer sufficient. Liquid coolingâ€”direct-to-chip and even immersion coolingâ€”is gaining ground, especially where densities exceed 50kW/rack. These systems require new plumbing, maintenance, and operational protocols.

Load Volatility: AI workloads are unpredictable, with training cycles spiking rapidly and inference jobs running continuously. Infrastructure must now be responsive, with real-time monitoring and adaptive power and cooling systems.

Commissioning Complexity: Testing and validating infrastructure for AI means simulating extreme loads and mixed cooling environments. Digital twins and advanced simulation tools are now essential in the design and commissioning process.

Power Constraints: Access to grid power is becoming a bottleneck in some regions, leading to on-site energy generation, storage solutions, and modular buildouts. Even brief power disruptions can have immediate thermal consequences in high-density AI deployments.

Heat Reuse: The immense heat generated by AI workloads is driving renewed interest in heat recovery and reuse, including integration with district heating systems and heat export capabilities.

Adaptability and Flexibility: The next generation of data centers must be fast, scalable, and adaptableâ€”able to manage high loads efficiently and respond in real time to changing demand.

As AI continues to evolve, so too must our approach to data center design and management. Investing in smarter, more resilient infrastructure is no longer optionalâ€”it's essential for organizations looking to harness the full potential of AI.

#AI #DataCenters #Infrastructure #ArtificialIntelligence #LiquidCooling #EdgeComputing #Sustainability #DigitalTransformation #TechInnovation #FutureOfWork

content:
Until he changes his mind...

Elon Musk ruled out a merger between Tesla and xAI but said he plans to hold a shareholder vote on investment in the artificial intelligence startup by the automaker, in the latest step to deepen integration across his business empire.

His comments followed aÂ The Wall Street Journal reportÂ on Saturday that SpaceX, Musk's rocket firm, will invest $2 billion in xAI as part of a $5 billion funding round aimed at keeping pace with rivals, including OpenAI in the capital-intensive AI race.

Musk, Tesla and xAI have not responded to Reuters requests for comment.
The billionaire's companies already share close ties. XAI's Grok chatbot is rolling out to the automaker's vehicles, and Tesla engineers assisted Musk after his 2022 buyout of Twitter, the social media platform now known as X.
Responding to a user post on X asking Tesla investors if they supported a merger between the two companies, Musk on Monday replied "No." 

He had said on Sunday he would ask Tesla shareholders to vote on whether the automaker can invest in xAI.

"If it was up to me, Tesla would have invested in xAI long ago," Musk had said on X, having previously signaled that close ties between the companies could help advance Tesla's autonomous-driving ambitions.

Integrating technology, talent and financial backing is a theme that runs across Musk's empire of companies. Earlier this year, xAI acquired Musk's X in a $33 billionÂ dealÂ that valued the combined group at $80 billion at the time.

That deal meant the X platform would come in handy to further distribute xAI products, while also providing a real-time feed of users' posts, screenshots and massive amounts of other data.

I think xAI including Twitter, Inc. is still burning a lot of cash, despite the infusion from SpaceX. This integration with Tesla would finance all these ideas with shareholder money and would increase Musk's share at Tesla to a level where he has more (maybe absolute) control. 

Not good for Tesla!

#automotiveindustry #electricvehicles #leadership #ai #tesla

content:
Absa Uganda: â€œThe house is big, but it leaks at the entranceâ€, Bunyoro proverb

That is exactly how Absa Ugandaâ€™s asset structure looks in 2024: grand on paper, but with hidden vulnerabilities few in the boardroom dare confront.
a) UGX 5.43 trillion in assets.
b) Ranked 3rd in the industry.
c) Growing, yes, but growing how, and towards what?
Â 
You see, every time I brief a Board, I ask: Are your assets sweating? Or just sitting there looking expensive?
Â 
Let us open the hood:
Â 
a) Nearly half of Absaâ€™s assets are in government securities â€“ risk-free but return-poor.
b) Loan book is only 36.6% of assets â€“ less than Centenary, Stanbic, or Baroda.
c) Cash and placements: UGX 1.28T in low-yield limbo.
d) Due from group companies â€“ are we funding the parent, or Ugandaâ€™s SMEs?
Â 
And then comes the real story, the deposits. Everyone claps at UGX 3.18T. Double-digit growth. Third in the market. But what no one says is this: â€œThese are not deposits. These are tourists.â€
Â 
Over 60% of Absaâ€™s deposit base is corporate and institutional: NGOs, embassies, regional suppliers, blue-chip treasuries.
Â 
a) They move fast.
c) They chase yield.
d) They vanish without warning.
Â 
Meanwhile, Centenary quietly builds sticky rural deposits. Equity embeds in diaspora remittance loops. Stanbic holds government-linked money with surgical lobbying.
Â 
But Absa? Slick app. Strong brand. But no retail anchor. No habit hook. No embedded loyalty. Instead of sweating assets, they are parking them. Instead of building daily banking behaviours, they are hawking 6-month fixed deposits.
Â 
This is what I call â€œBalance sheet gaming.â€
Â 
A perfect show, until the curtain falls.
Â 
In Part 2, we go even deeper:
Â 
a) Revenue â€“ the engine power.
b) Profit after tax â€“ what is really left on the table.
c) NPA â€“ the termites in the woodwork.
d) ROE & ROA â€“ the real tests of relevance.
d) Non-interest income â€“ the quiet differentiator.
e) Cost of deposits â€“ is growth bleeding margin?
f) Yield on loans â€“ are they lending wisely or dangerously?
g) Loan-to-deposit ratio â€“ hoarding vs deploying.
Â 
Now I want to hear from you: Which bank is your primary banker, and why? Which bank do you hate, and what did they do to earn it?
What do you want me to cover in Part 2 of the above 8 areas?
Â 
If we hit 120 comments or reposts, I will share Part 2 with full insights, lending data, and profit structure breakdowns.
Â 
I brief boards across Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, and Zambia.
Nigeria, call me. I am ready.
Â 
Every board has its own internal data analysis & business intelligence team. But remember this:
Â 
No car inhales its own exhaust.
Â 
That is why forward-looking Boards invite me. Not to flatter. Not to recycle internal slides. But to offer an external view that:
Â 
a) Exposes blind spots.
b) Forces strategic clarity.
c) Unlocks transformation.
Â 
If your Board is serious about staying ahead of the curve, I am ready to speak. Send me a DM. Let us stir the mud.
Â 
Yours, Mr Strategy.

Oracle BI Lead Technical Consultant
Job Summary
Job Requirements / Details (Skill: Oracle BI (OBIEE) Experience: 7-10 Years,
Location: Miami, Florida, USA)


Job Summary
The Lead Consultant (Oracle BI) plays a crucial role in providing expertise and guidance in Oracle BI technologies to support business intelligence solutions for clients. The primary responsibility is to design, develop, and implement Oracle BI solutions that drive data driven decision-making and enhance overall business performance.
Key Responsibilities
1. Collaborate with stakeholders to gather requirements and understand business needs for oracle bi solutions.
2. Design and develop oracle bi solutions, including data modeling, etl processes, and creating reports and dashboards.
3. Provide technical leadership and guidance to project teams in the implementation and maintenance of oracle bi solutions.
4. Conduct performance tuning, troubleshooting, and optimization of oracle bi applications.
5. Stay updated on oracle bi best practices, new features, and technologies to propose innovative solutions.
6. Ensure the quality, security, and scalability of oracle bi solutions delivered to clients.

Skill Requirements

Â 
Proficiency in Oracle BI technologies such as oracle business intelligence enterprise edition (OBIEE), Oracle BI publisher, and oracle analytics cloud.
Strong knowledge of data modeling, ETL processes, and data visualization techniques.
Experience in designing and developing reports, dashboards, and analytics using oracle bi tools.
Ability to troubleshoot and optimize oracle bi applications for performance enhancements.
Excellent communication and interpersonal skills to collaborate with stakeholders and project teams effectively.
Experience in OBIEE RPD modeling, designing start/snowflake schemas
OBIEE Expert with a thorough understanding of OBIEE architecture and the role of different OBIEE components like Analytic Server, Web Server, RPD, Web Catalog, Security, Dashboards, Reports, iBots and Scheduler
Experience in writing and profiling complex PL/SQL queries and fetch appropriate data from huge data sets efficiently (Oracle)
Experience in OBIEE Features (i.e. Cache, Usage tracking, Dimensional hierarchy, Variables/Initialization Blocks configuration etc.), converting Snow-Flake Schema to Star Schema, Dim Hierarchies, Dim Extensions, and Physical & Logical Data Modeling.
Possess good communication, interpersonal skills, an ability to quickly grasp new concepts- both technical and business related. Flexible and experienced to work independently or in a team environment.
Â 
Education/Experience:Â Bachelorâ€™s Degree or equivalent in Computer Science, Information Systems or related field and 6-10 years of relevant experience.
Specialization Domains:Â Supply Chain, Warehouse Management Distribution
Technologies:Â Oracle BI - OBIEE, Oracle Database tools like TOAD, SQL Plus and Oracle tools
please share your profile to kumartripathysusant@gmail.com

content:
We Didnâ€™t Hire Two Software Engineers. We Built Them.

Had a very interesting conversation a week ago with a COO who has responsibility for Technology in his company. When I asked him. "So, what's new these days?", the first words that came out of his mouth were: "We just built 2 engineers" - Hmm. It took me a second to process what he really meant. Instead of hiring two software engineers to take on software development work, they had built them as AI agents.

They now have two fully functioning AI engineers embedded in their team, designed to augment and enhance how they work, not replace the people who already do it. He then said "That mindset shift has changed everything in our company." Instead of asking, â€œWho can we eliminate?â€ we asked, â€œHow can we give our team extra power?â€

It was refreshing for me to hear this as you know I talk a lot about this topic. Thereâ€™s a lot of noise about AI taking jobs. But for them, it was simple:

They chose augmentation over replacement. These AI engineers handle code generation, documentation, QA checks, even sprint prep, still at a junior level but theyâ€™re not here to push people out, theyâ€™re here to amplify the creativity and impact of the humans around them. 

AI isnâ€™t that scary when you put people at the center. Hereâ€™s then what I recommended for him to consider so the shift feels even more empowering.

Name your engineers (agents), give them a personality. Your AI agents are part of the team. They should even get nicknames.

Be vocal about the quick wins. â€œIf your AI engineer agent just reduced your development time by 20-30% then share itâ€, that builds confidence in the technology and most importantly in the mindset across your company.

Train your entire team and organization on prompting. Have them take a course and setup a "train the trainer" model.

He agreed to do these things and told me he would report back in 90 days to see how "the experiment" goes. I hope to get the phone call from him and not from one of the AI Engineers ğŸ™‚ 

Have you thought about what if we stopped asking â€œWill AI replace jobs?â€ and instead embrace AI and start asking â€œWhat roles can AI agents play on our teams?â€

We all should think about designing a new kind of workforce, where humans and AI agents work together. What role would your first AI agent play in your company?

#AIinBusiness #AgenticAI #WorkforceTransformation #Leadership #DigitalTransformation #AIEngineers #FutureOfWork #CIO

content:
Lately, Iâ€™ve been thinking about a quote we discussed in my Strategy Leadership course at Stanford:
â€œI may be wrong, but at least Iâ€™m not confused.â€ Jeff Miller, former CEO of Documentum.
At first, it made me smile. It sounded like something a bold leader says when theyâ€™re about to make a risky call.
But the more I sat with it, the more I realized how much depth and truth it holds especially in times of uncertainty and fast change.
Because the reality is: being wrong is something we can usually fix.
A wrong turn can be corrected, assumptions can be revisited, and decisions can be revised.
But being confused? Or worse, leading without clarity? Thatâ€™s a far deeper risk that quietly paralyzes teams and keeps organizations stuck in loops of inaction.
And that brings me to what weâ€™re living through right now with AI.
Almost every conversation Iâ€™ve had lately with executives, educators, founders, and leaders in between carries this undertone:
â€œWe know AI is important, weâ€™re just not sure how it fits yet.â€
Or: â€œWe donâ€™t want to move too fast and get it wrong.â€
And I get it.
This space is evolving daily. New tools are emerging. New risks are being uncovered. No one has the perfect roadmap.
But hereâ€™s the thing: waiting for perfect clarity is not a strategy.
Leadership is not about knowing all the answers : itâ€™s about helping people move forward in a world where no one does.
One of the most powerful ideas we explored at Stanford was that strategy isnâ€™t a slogan. Itâ€™s not a vision statement or a static 30-page plan.
Strategy is, at its core, a logic : a working theory of how your organization will win, grounded in reality, flexible enough to evolve, and clear enough to guide everyday decisions.
But that logic only holds if the assumptions underneath it are sound.
This is why AI is now a strategic conversation not just a technical one.
Because it is actively reshaping customer expectations, operational models, and competitive advantage in real time.
And the leaders who wait until they feel completely ready will likely find themselves trying to catch up from behind.
So if youâ€™re leading a team, a department, or a business right now, I want to offer this thought:
You donâ€™t need to be an AI expert.
But you do need to develop a point of view.
You need to understand whatâ€™s happening in the market, in your industry, and beyond your immediate line of sight.
You need to educate yourselfâ€”and then help your team connect the dots.
 Because theyâ€™re looking to you to make sense of this moment, and to provide direction even if the path isnâ€™t fully lit.

And in that sense, Jeff Miller was absolutely right:
You may be wrong.
But as long as you're not confused, you're leading.
#Leadership #Strategy #AIinBusiness #StanfordGSB #ExecutiveEducation #EmergingStrategy #AILeadership #ChangeLeadership #GenerativeAI

content:
You are the Asset NOT ChatGPT

Â The advent of AI and ChatGPT in our business has been an extremely effective tool, which I use almost every day.Â  As AI continues to evolve, Brokers should look at how AI tools can streamline their business and make them more efficient.Â  On the flip side I have also started to see an over reliance on ChatGPT from Brokers to do their job.Â  I think it is important to not forget that you as the Agent are the asset, not ChatGPT.Â  AI will ABSOLUTELY have a major role in our industry, likely in more ways than we can imagine, but we can't solely rely on AI to do our job. Mark Cuban put it perfectly when he said AI should be aÂ tool, not
the answer.

I woke up to an email that said, â€œI couldnâ€™t figure out the comps, but this is what ChatGPT thinks the property is worth.â€ One of the biggest complaints Iâ€™ve had as a Broker mentoring newer Agents is the phrase,Â â€œThere are no comps.â€Â Now weâ€™ve entered a new era,Â â€œThere are no comps, but this is what ChatGPT thinks it is worth.â€Â Please help meÂ ğŸ¤¦â€â™€ï¸Â . ChatGPT was wrong. It was a very specific deal where things change Street by Street, Block by Block.

I recently asked ChatGPT to draft a response to an email I had received. The reply was beautifully written, but it didnâ€™t reflect my personality or style at all. Most people are surprised when they meet me because of how chatty I am. I donâ€™t consider myself a writer, and most of my emails are short and to the point. Sending the ChatGPT generated response felt completely inauthentic to who I am. They also would have wondered, who is this person?

I have seen an overreliance on using Chat GPT to answer every email and even texts.Â Â On one occasion I had sent a text expressing my frustration, and the response I received was clearly AI-generated. It didnâ€™t match the tone or way the person normally speaks. My immediate reaction was,Â â€œOh, here we go, you needed ChatGPT to tell you how to respond to me.â€Â That realization only made me more frustrated. I donâ€™t want to talk to a computer when navigating a deal. I want to talk to theÂ person. To anyone who thinks itâ€™s not obvious when a response is AI-generated, it is.

As Brokers we need to use AI to complement our business, not do it for us. As commercial real estate Brokers, we deal not only with complex transactions, but we also deal with complex personalities. AI can support us in our business, butÂ we are the asset. Clients hire Brokers for their skill sets and their ability to navigate difficult situations. As Brokers, we rely on critical thinking to navigate challenging deals. Those experiences make us a better Broker. Brokers need to understand their value and why they were hired in the first place. If you pair this with AI advancements, Brokers will shine.

#AI #AIinBusiness #realestate #cre #losangelesrealestate #business #AIrealestate

ğŸ§µ RAG + Knowledge Graphs = Enterprise Memory Architecture

The modern enterprise doesn't just need intelligence.
It needs memory.

LLMs like GPT or Claude are brilliant at generating responses but suffer from short-term memory loss. 
They hallucinate. 
They forget. 
They donâ€™t know what you already know.

Enter the power couple: RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) and Knowledge Graphs.

While RAG lets LLMs pull relevant, factual content from enterprise data in real time, knowledge graphs provide context, structure, and traceability.

Together, they form the backbone of what I call an Enterprise Memory Architecture:

âœ… Persistent organizational knowledge 
âœ… Reduced hallucinations and redundancy 
âœ… Contextual and compliant AI answers 
âœ… Explainability for regulated sectors

Think of it as: LLM = the brain; RAG = the external hard drive; Knowledge Graph = the filing system.

Forward-thinking enterprises are already moving beyond just plugging LLMs into chatbots. They're designing memory-driven systems that evolve, learn, and remember.

Want AI that thinks like your company? 
Start by giving it a memory.

content:
HS2's CEO admitted they built trains "too fast" and to "too high a specification."

The potential result? Billions in cost overruns and years of delays because, as he put it, "there was such zealotry about the highest speed in a relatively small country."

Transport engineers saw this coming. Infrastructure specialists flagged the over-specification. Project managers warned about starting construction before design maturity.

But who was listening?

This isn't unique to HS2. Housing policies get designed without consulting developers who understand local markets. NHS reforms roll out without input from frontline staff who see the daily reality. Economic policies launch without regional business intelligence that could predict real-world impacts.

Your MP needs the expertise sitting in their constituency. The accountant who spots the budget flaw. The teacher who knows why the education reform won't work. The small business owner who can predict the policy's unintended consequences.

Your insight could prevent the next Â£100 billion mistake.

That question haunted me early in my leadership journey. I thought I was doing everything rightâ€”checking in regularly, staying involved, ensuring qualityâ€¦

âŒ Constant updates

That day, I made a conscious shift:
âœ¨ I started trusting more, managing less
 âœ¨ I learned to delegate not just tasks, but ownership
 âœ¨ I gave space to failâ€”and room to grow
 âœ¨ I replaced control with clarity, coaching, and compassion

ğŸ‘‰ Today, when someone brings up micromanagement, I don't just offer tipsâ€”I offer the transformation Iâ€™ve lived through.
If youâ€™re a manager, ask yourself:

Because micromanagement is not about bad intentionsâ€”it's often just misplaced fears. But unaddressed, it can silently erode trust, creativity, and morale.

So letâ€™s flip the narrative:

content:
ğŸ” SAP Analytics Cloud: Powerful Insights, But Is Your Security Keeping Up?

Â As organizations increasingly adopt SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) to unify analytics, planning, and predictive capabilities, one important question is often overlooked:

Is your SAC environment secure and audit-ready? 

While SAC enables smarter decisions, it also introduces unique security and compliance risks that must be addressed â€” especially by those of us in SAP Security and Audit roles.

Â ğŸ“Š What is SAP Analytics Cloud? 

SAP Analytics Cloud is SAPâ€™s all-in-one platform for:Â 
>Â Business Intelligence (dashboards, reports),
>Â Planning (budgeting, forecasting), an
>Â Predictive Analytics (smart insights, forecasting models)
It connects with a variety of data sources â€” including SAP S/4HANA, BW, HANA, and non-SAP platforms â€” and brings analytics closer to business decisions.
But with great access comes great responsibility.
Â 
ğŸ” Key SAP Security Considerations in SAC

Â 1. User Access & Identity ManagementÂ 
>Â Is user access being provisioned and deprovisioned centrally?Â 
>Â Are you leveraging Single Sign-On (SSO) and/or federated identity management?Â 
>Â Are inactive or external users being periodically reviewed?
Â Â 
2. Role Design and Access Control
Â SAC uses its own Roles and Teams to manage authorizations â€” different from traditional SAP roles.Â 
>Â Is the principle of least privilege followed when assigning roles?
>Â Are sensitive data models protected with row-level or object-level security?

3. Audit Logging & Monitoring
SAC provides audit logs capturing user activity like report access, data exports, model changes, etc.Â 
>Â Are these logs being monitored regularly?
>Â Is there an alert mechanism for unusual behavior (e.g., mass exports or unauthorized access)?

Â 4. Data Security in Live Connections
>Â SAC supports live and import data connections.
>Â Are connections to SAP S/4, BW, or HANA secured with encryption?
>Â Are credentials and access tokens stored securely?

Â âœ… From an Auditorâ€™s Perspective

Â For audit and compliance teams, the following should be top of mind:

Â > User Access Review: Are all users still valid? Are any roles overly permissive?
Â > Change History: Can you track who changed what â€” be it in dashboards, models, or access rights?
Â > Segregation of Duties (SoD): Though SAC doesnâ€™t natively integrate with GRC tools, are you manually reviewing for SoD violations?
Â > License Consumption: Are users appropriately categorized (viewer, planner, BI user)? Misclassification can lead to audit findings or cost overruns.

Â ğŸŒŸ Final Thoughts 

SAP Analytics Cloud is transforming enterprise decision-making â€” but as SAP Security professionals, we must ensure that security, access, and auditability evolve in parallel with technology.

ğŸ’¬ Is SAC part of your SAP Security or audit scope yet?
Iâ€™d love to hear how your organization is approaching SAC governance.

content:
OLTP vs OLAP in Data Engineering



Understanding the difference between OLTP and OLAP is crucial for any Data Engineer, especially when working with data pipelines, data warehouses, or big data systems.





OLTP (Online Transaction Processing)



Purpose: Handles day-to-day transactional data

Use Case: Banking systems, e-commerce apps, booking systems

Operations: Insert, Update, Delete, Read (CRUD)

Data Volume: Small, but high frequency

Schema Design: Highly normalized (to reduce redundancy)

Latency: Low latency, fast response time for small queries

Example: When you book a train ticket or make an online payment



OLAP (Online Analytical Processing)



Purpose: Designed for complex queries and analytics

Use Case: Business Intelligence, Reporting Dashboards, Data Warehouses

Operations: Read-heavy; Aggregations, Joins, Slicing, Dicing

Data Volume: Large volumes (historical + aggregated data)

Schema Design: Denormalized (e.g., Star or Snowflake Schema)

Latency: Higher latency acceptable for complex analytical queries

Example: Monthly sales trend report across regions and product lines

content:
Most "AI procurement" platforms are basic automation wearing an AI costume.
I spent 6 months exposing their tricks.
Here's how to spot vaporware in 5 minutes:

One vendor showed their "AI" risk tool. Sci-fi dashboard, 95% accuracy. 

Behind the curtain? 

It was checking if invoices were late. 
That's not AI. That's an IF statement with makeup.

I witnessed enterprises spend millions on "machine learning" that was just keyword matching. They paid Ferrari prices for a Honda with racing stripes.

The truth vendors hide: 

Real AI learns and evolves. Fake AI follows fixed rules forever.

Test them: "Show me how your predictions improved over 12 months."

Watch them squirm.

3 red flags:

â€¢ No training data discussion
â€¢ Works "perfectly" on day one
â€¢ Vague "proprietary algorithms"

Real AI starts messy. Gets smarter monthly. 
It shows confidence scores, not certainties.

Expose fakes by requesting:

1. Live data processing
2. Model architecture explanation
3. Performance variance metrics

If they deflect, you've found vaporware.

We've evaluated dozens of platforms... 
and identified which delivers 30-40% savings. 

Most don't.

Leaderâ€™s perspectives I "AI at Work: Transforming with Deloitte, SAP and AWS"

@Netra Saxena, Associate Director, Deloitte India, spoke passionately about how AI can be applied to real business processes, not just as a concept but as a value-driving engine across industries. She shared how these AI solutions are delivered using SAP BTP and how they can be seamlessly lifted and shifted to other hyperscalers to align with clientsâ€™ infrastructure preferences. A highlight of the session was the introduction of a new platform offering, AgentX, which enables end-to-end business process orchestration powered by Agentic AI. With AgentX, organisations can move beyond traditional automation and empower digital agents to reason, act and collaborate across systems.

Real use cases showcased:
â€¢ Smart reporting: Build real-time, on-demand reports with embedded insights, removing the dependency on static dashboards or BI teams.
â€¢ Intelligent invoicing: Automate the extraction of invoice details from documents and trigger direct posting into ERP systems with validation checks, reducing cycle time and manual effort.
â€¢ Concept to case: Turn ideas into structured business cases using GenAI, instantly capturing problem statements, benefits, dependencies and ROI narratives.

Together, these solutions show how AI is already delivering measurable results, helping organisations drive efficiency, agility and long-term strategic impact.

content:
#SQL Mastery: Understanding #ROLLUP & #CUBE for Smart Reporting

ROLLUP adds subtotals and grand totals to your grouped data.
It performs a hierarchical aggregation from the most detailed level up to the grand total.

CUBE adds all possible combinations of subtotals across multiple dimensions.
Itâ€™s like ROLLUP, but it gives all groupings, not just hierarchical ones.
Â 
Why Do We Need ROLLUP and CUBE?
To quickly calculate subtotals and totals without writing multiple queries.
For summary reports, dashboards, and OLAP-style analysis.
To analyze data across multiple dimensions like product, region, time, etc.

When Do We Use Them?
   Scenario                                                                                     
   1. You want totals by region and a grand total                       â†’ Use ROLLUP
   2. You want subtotals for every combination (region, product)â†’  Use CUBE
   3. Building sales reports or business intelligence dashboards  â†’    âœ…
   4. Performing multidimensional analysis (e.g. pivot tables)      â†’ Â Â Â âœ…
  Â 
Interpreting NULLs in ROLLUP/CUBE:
NULL values represent totals or aggregated levels.
Example:
region = 'East', product = NULL â†’ subtotal for region
region = NULL, product = NULL â†’ grand total

Say goodbye to writing multiple UNIONs or subqueries.
 With ROLLUP and CUBE, you let SQL handle the heavy lifting!

#SQL #DataAnalytics #BusinessIntelligence #SQLTips #PivotTables #DataReporting #ROLLUP #CUBE #DataEngineer #DataProfessional

Yolo Group, the operator of Sportsbet.io and Bitcasino, has appointed Stephanie Eddy, a former Betway Commercial Development Director, as its new Chief Revenue Officer. With over ten years of experience at Betway, Eddy will be responsible for driving the company's commercial success across key markets and strategic channels, focusing on revenue growth and optimizing customer acquisition strategies. Her appointment highlights Yolo Entertainment's commitment to expanding its global footprint and enhancing its brand and product offerings.

CEO Matthew D'Emanuele expressed enthusiasm about Eddyâ€™s addition, emphasizing her strategic vision and leadership qualities that align with the company's growth objectives. Eddy herself noted her excitement to contribute to Yolo Entertainmentâ€™s innovative approach in gaming and crypto and to elevate its flagship brands. Recently, the company has strengthened its leadership team by hiring industry experts in CRM, content, product engineering, and business intelligence, signaling a strategic push toward further growth and market expansion.

content:
My colleague John Quillinan is looking to start a DAMA chapter in Central Florida.  His message is below - if you are interested, please reach out to him directly:
------
I am looking to start a central florida chapter of DAMA,Â Can I count on you to be one of the founding members?Â If so, I need the information listed below.

The mission of the chapter would be to act of local arm of DAMA, recruiting members and conducting events, including workshops to prepare members for the CDMP Foundations exam. We could bring in speakers on Data Modeling, Data Integration, Data Warehousing, Data Governance, and Master Data Management, just to name a few. Another topic could be using Gen AI to curate data, such as master data attributes in retail, and using the same technology to identify and remediate data quality issues.Obviously, there are many other topics, but this is what I am sharing with my colleagues in the interim.

I have started reaching out to some of my colleagues in the area, most of which work in analytics and hospitality. Our coverage would need to be coast to coast, i.e., Tampa/St Pete to Daytona Beach/Titusville. Can you think of anyone that would be interested in starting a local chapter of DAMA in Central Florida.Â 
Â 
John

content:
Today, we mourn the loss of a remarkable advocate for enhancing access and quality of care in underserved communities. Eddie Tantoco, former Special Forces member who played a pivotal role in the merger of Marriott Hotels and Starwood, dedicated his life to serving those in need.

I had the privilege of collaborating with Eddie on numerous initiatives aimed at addressing the root causes of inadequate healthcare policies. He was not just a colleague but a partner in supporting tribal communities, a mentor in fostering relationships, a powerhouse in business intelligence - our very own "Rambo," and above all, a loyal friend with boundless energy and unwavering spirit.

Rest peacefully, Eddie. Your vision will endure, and your legacy will continue to save countless lives. Heidi Bernardo Erica Sun Tuan D. Nguyen, ALM Indian Health Service Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) PAC

content:
ğŸ“SQL Support: Depth Powers Enterprise Data

In enterprise data platforms, SQL drives analytics, governance, and automation. Snowflake and Databricks offer modern SQL, but their implementation details shape enterprise use cases. Below is a technical comparison of key SQL features for SQL-centric teams.

âœ… QUALIFY Clause
Snowflake: supports filtering on window functions including in nested subqueries and alongside aggregates
Databricks: has limited support (only elementary window expressions), often requiring CTEs or subqueries for more complex filtering 

âœ… MATCH_RECOGNIZE
Snowflake: fully implements SQL:2016 pattern recognition (DEFINE, MEASURES, PATTERN)
Databricks: does not support this clause, requiring workarounds via Spark APIs or code

âœ… WITH RECURSIVE
Snowflake: handles hierarchies and graphs with WITH RECURSIVE.
Databricks: lacks native support so users must resort to iterative Spark graph APIs or loops

âœ… FLATTEN() & LATERAL Joins
Snowflake: provides FLATTEN() and true LATERAL joins for semi-structured data (e.g. JSON arrays)
Databricks: relies on explode() or inline(), which are less intuitive for SQL users and need additional tuning

âœ… Time Travel via CHANGES(...)
Snowflake: offers declarative change tracking and versioned queries via CHANGES(...)
Databricks: supports time travel with Delta Lake, but lacks a SQL-native equivalent and requires manual configuration or Spark APIs

âœ… CREATE STREAM (CDC)
Snowflake: enables CDC through SQL-native CREATE STREAM
Databricks: uses Delta change data feeds and Spark streaming this approach is powerful but more engineering-heavy

âœ… CREATE TASK
Snowflake: supports cron-based task scheduling within SQL
Databricks: requires notebooks or external orchestrators (e.g. Airflow, Jobs API) for automation

âœ… Materialized Views
Snowflake: supported with joins and aggregations that auto-refresh
Databricks: offers only non-materialized views,materialization requires custom Delta tables or Delta Live Tables

âœ… EXECUTE IMMEDIATE & Dynamic SQL
Snowflake:s upports dynamic SQL and procedural scripting with EXECUTE IMMEDIATE
Databricks: SQL lacks this, so users often shift to Python/Scala for dynamic workflows

âœ… Sequences
Snowflake: provides SQL-native CREATE SEQUENCE and NEXTVAL
Databricks: lacks sequences use alternatives like monotonically_increasing_id() are available but less straightforward in SQL

âœ… Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
Snowflake: natively supports column-level masking, row access policies, and tag-based governance in SQL
Databricks: has robust governance via Unity Catalog, but it is more workspace-centric and less embedded in SQL syntax 

Takeaway
Snowflake offers deeper SQL-native features, enabling faster, cleaner architectures. Databricks leans on Spark, fragmenting SQL workflows. These differences impact productivity and scalability for data engineers and analysts.

#DataEngineering #SQL #Snowflake #Databricks #Analytics

P.S. Databricks fans, letâ€™s keep it tech-focused ,share your insights!

content:
I just sent out this week's "5 freeCodeCamp resources worth your time." Some heaters in here including a 2-hour course on agentic "vibe coding" with n8n.

1. freeCodeCamp just published this comprehensive course that will teach you how to build apps using the LAMP Stack â€“ Linux, Apache, MySQL, PHP. This is a classic toolchain that a huge number of websites still use to this day. You can code along at home and build your own clone of Google Calendar â€“ complete with multi-appointment support and booking conflict logic. Then you'll use JavaScript to add a dynamic user interface. This project will help you expand your horizons and get in some serious reps. (3 hour YouTube course): https://lnkd.in/gw56n5dr

2. You may have heard the term â€œvibe codingâ€, where you write the specifications for your app, then hand it over to code generation agents who write the code for you. This approach has been a bit polarizing in the developer community, with vocal critics and vocal advocates. My advice is don't listen to any of them. Think for yourself. freeCodeCamp just published this course that will introduce you to vibe coding tools like n8n â€“ an open source workflow automation tool â€“ so you can wire together APIs and services without needing to write a ton of code manually. (2 hour YouTube course): https://lnkd.in/gzM6-9ws

3. On this week's podcast I interview Joe Hill. He's a software engineer who works on a data platform for NASA. Joe taught himself programming for 4 years while working as a janitor. As the single father of two Autistic boys, he first used his programming skills to build an iPad app to help them learn how to talk. He shares tons of practical tips for learning new skills and for getting things done inside big orgs. (1 hour watch or listen in your favorite podcast app): https://lnkd.in/gsvEUU-E

4. Learn how to write Python tests so you can make your codebase more robust. This tutorial will teach you the basics of pytest and show you tons of examples. You'll learn about Markers, Fixtures, Parameterization, and more. (20 minute read): https://lnkd.in/gafgJ8nq

5. Tell your gardener friends: freeCodeCamp just published a tutorial on how to monitor the moisture of your soil using an Arduino microcontroller. This tutorial will show you what hardware to get and how to wire it up. Then it'll walk you through the code you'll run, and explain how everything works. (30 minute read): https://lnkd.in/gggjuHhU

Quote of the Week: 
â€œBecoming tool agnostic is one of the biggest strengths you will ever have as a programmer. If you walk into a place and they say â€œwe use XYZâ€, you can go â€œGreat. I'll learn it.â€ That is so powerful.â€ - Joe Hill on this week's podcast

content:
Belgian NAVY Reservists Visit GEOxyz â€“ Exploring Innovation in Maritime Operations 
This week, GEOxyz had the honour of welcoming a group of reservists from the Belgian Navy, currently following their Specialized Professional Training (GPO). As part of their program, the reservists visited our technical HUB at Ostend for an introduction into the world of advanced maritime technology.
The highlight of the visit was a tour of our Remote Operations Room, where we operate our fleet of autonomous vessels used in surveillance and surveying. These systems represent the forefront of innovation in unmanned maritime operations.
For the reservists, this was a valuable opportunity to explore how cutting-edge technology is transforming the maritime landscape. It also provided concrete insight into the growing role of automation, data and remote capabilities.
By bridging defense training with commercial technology applications, we collectively invest in safer, smarter, and more efficient maritime operations and foster mutual understanding, cross-sector learning and stimulate innovation
A sincere thank you to the reservists and the Belgian Naval Component for their visit and their commitment!

Excited to share that Iâ€™ve successfully implemented an end-to-end Playwright test automation framework powered by MCP  for intelligent test generation â€” integrated with Jenkins CI/CD and Allure Reporting for actionable insights.

ğŸ’¡ What is MCP?
Model Context Protocol (MCP) is a next-gen approach to generating test cases automatically based on context-aware business flows. Instead of writing every test manually, MCP helps generate meaningful scenarios faster, improving coverage and productivity.

ğŸ”§ Highlights of the Framework:
âœ… Auto-generated Playwright tests using MCP
 âœ… Jenkins pipeline for seamless CI/CD integration
 âœ… Beautiful & actionable reports using Allure
 âœ… Clean modular structure, easy to scale and maintain
 âœ… Working locally and in Jenkins build environments

ğŸ›  Step-by-Step Guide: Jenkins + Playwright + Allure Integration

âœ… Step 1: Create Jenkinsfile to Your Local Project
âœ… Step 2: Launch Jenkins and Install Required Jenkins Plugins
Go to Manage Jenkins > Plugins and install:
âœ… NodeJS Plugin
âœ… Allure Jenkins Plugin
âœ… Pipeline Plugin (already available in most Jenkins installations)
âœ… Step 3: Configure Tools in Jenkins
Navigate to:
 Manage Jenkins > Global Tool Configuration
NodeJS
Add a new NodeJS installation named: NodeJS 18
Enable â€œInstall automaticallyâ€
Choose a version like 18.x or latest
Allure Commandline
Add a new Allure commandline installation
Give it a name (e.g., Allure_Latest_LTS)
Select "Install automatically" with version 2.34.1
âœ… Step 4: Set Up Your Jenkins Project
Create a new pipeline job in Jenkins
Select Pipeline script from SCM
Choose Git and paste your GitHub repo URL
 Example: https://lnkd.in/gQzg_7zr
Make sure the branch is set to main (or whichever you're using)
âœ… Step 5: Trigger Build
Once everything is configured:
Click "Build Now"
Jenkins will:
Clone the repo
Install dependencies
Run Playwright tests
Generate Allure results
Publish the report
âœ… Step 6: View the Allure Report
After build finishes, go to the job â†’ Allure Report link will appear in the left menu.
View detailed reports with test steps, logs, attachments, and trends.
âœ… Optional: Run Locally (CLI)
npx playwright test --project=chromium
npx allure generate ./allure-results --clean -o ./allure-report
npx allure open ./allure-report

content:
I have coached 15+ startups with wildly different outcomes. Yet the billion dollar trajectories share some common DNA. Vinod Khosla calls this the difference between $0M and $0B companies. Here are six patterns that I have found useful and am actively wiring into Zeer AI from day one:

1. Turn goals into systems and automations : 

Relentless focus on goals can kill your venture. Hitting targets is valuable ONLY if, in the process you are also building repeatable systems and engines to hit future goals. High growth teams automate todayâ€™s work so tomorrowâ€™s organizational complexity and growth get subsidized.Â  

2. Iterate relentlessly without losing your plot : 

Great companies pivot constantly while staying consistent. Each adjustment sharpens the vision instead of derailing it. When the pace of learning is massive, it shows up as continuous refinements to the original plan. To an outsider it might appear as a distraction. At Zeer we had numerous pivots. Each pivot has clarified our original mission and uncovered smarter and more efficient ways to solve the problem. 

3. Build teams that are intellectually curious : 

The best solutions that I've seen were powered by raw curiosity, a willingness to take risks, and a culture that made failure and risk taking safe. True breakthroughs come from first principles thinking while pursuing simplicity and not by copying someone elseâ€™s playbook. Work experience without first principles thinking can actually drag the team backwards with over reliance on cognitive bias. 

4. Tackle difficult problems and a big vision :

Billion dollar companies donâ€™t (often) chase end point solutions. They build platforms or compound companies and solve difficult problems. They pursue an audacious vision while shipping a simple monetizable slice of customer experience. Balancing todayâ€™s execution with tomorrowâ€™s dreams is a tough balancing act but the founders who nail this are the ones that make it big. 

5. Craft a Simple Narrative, Build a massive distribution :

Having a bold vision is not enough. Repetitive focus on simplifying the narrative and creating a massive distribution to broadcast the narrative is almost as important as the product and solution. A clear, simple repeatable narrative reduces friction and subsidizes the future. This narrative also brings in capital, early employees and customers. 

6. Question everything :

In most companies, the biggest resource wastage happens in the gap between a bad decision and itâ€™s correction. When a strategy, new hire or vendor is not working out - act fast. Everybody that had to take a tough decision wishes they had done it sooner. I review my assumptions every two weeks, even the good ones. I need to be convinced that we are on the right path. In the age of AI, this cadence is not optional but key to survival and speed.Â  

Which of these six resonates most with your team ? 

Please drop a note. Iâ€™m always up for swapping build-in-public lessons.

â€œWhen teams align with purpose, even the most complex projects turn into success stories.â€

I had the privilege of leading and collaborating with an extraordinary team on the account â€” an experience that will always remain one of the most defining chapters of my professional journey.
At the core of this success was Andrew Dorney, whose calm, clear, and strategic leadership laid the foundation for collaboration and trust across functions.

Takeaway:
 Success isnâ€™t just about technical milestones â€” itâ€™s about people showing up with passion, clarity, and ownership.

content:
I'm shocked people still don't use ChatGPT for job searching.

Copy and paste these 6 ChatGPT prompts to land your dream job:

1. LinkedIn Profile Optimization for Job Seekers:

Enhance profile for job hunting, focusing on [Title] role in [Specific Industry/Field].

Highlight experience in [Specific Field/Technology] to attract recruiters at [Company].

2. LinkedIn Connection Message for Job Opportunity:

Draft a LinkedIn message to connect with someone working at [Company].

Express your interest in the [Title] position and discuss why your background in [Specific Field/Technology] positions you as a prime candidate.

3. Creating Professional Resume :

Construct a resume for the [Title] role at [company], detailing [X] years of experience. Include 3-5 bullet points per position and incorporate 10 key phrases from the job description.

4. Crafting a Cover Letter:
